posted_at: {'date': '2025-11-26 06:55:38', 'relative': '1 week ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1764136538717}
text:
Someone asked advice for engineers & founders to get fit and stay fit while spending 10-12hr/day working on the computer. What one can do is so simple that most will find it hard to follow. 

#1 Get out of your home the moment you wake up. Hit the gym, go for a run. Do anything that moves your body. 

#2 Don’t touch your phone untill you’re done with #1. Your mind shouldn’t be reacting before your body wakes up. 

#3 On days you can’t do the #1, get min 10k steps. Take calls while walking and meetings on the move. Your work always doesn’t need your chair. 

#4 Eat as if your life depends on it. Whole foods always first. Don’t make your body a profit center for others. 

#5 Sleep like you are paid to do it. No health hack beats 7–8 hours of recovery. 

Btw, you can do all the above but if you don’t learn to deal the chaos in your head and bullshit people around you, you’re still going to be unhealthy & unfit. 

Ignoring some people for your mental health is not a weakness. It is your superpower.

Most engineers & founders want an optimal protocol. The real value is in the boring things that you’ve to keep doing consistently. Your health is the real moat.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-11-22 06:57:47', 'relative': '1 week ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1763791067391}
text:
We have some of the most talented founders in India solving real problems but don’t get enough attention. We met a founder who served as a doctor in the Indian Army. And now is building a smart stethoscope that helps doctors detect heart and lung disorders early and accurately.

Why this matters- India has a severe shortage of cardiologists and one of the highest rates of premature deaths from cardiac and respiratory diseases. Most clinics especially in rural areas don’t have specialists or advanced diagnostics.

His solution, AiSteth, uses AI to screen and detects cardio respiratory disorders early, making high quality diagnosis affordable and accessible to every clinic, even with limited staff or equipment.

We may not build the next Tesla or AGI  but we have founders who are quietly fixing the hard problems nobody else wants to touch. This is the kind of innovation India needs.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-11-19 06:12:59', 'relative': '2 weeks ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1763529179576}
text:
Amul has evolved from a dairy to a nutrition brand and is probably the most underrated case study in modern day business. They did a revenue of 90,000cr in FY25. Hard to think of another company in the world that has done something similar. Notes on what i think they got right..

1) They innovate at cooperative speed not startup speed and still wins. Launched 250 product launches in 5 years and that's crazy speed for a cooperative with millions of farmers, 18000+ village societies, and government-linked processes. Most companies will shiver at this speed.

2) They turned cold chain into a moat decades before most startups spoke about supply chain tech. They run India’s largest cold supply chain with refrigeration networks across rural area and temperature controlled logistics in small towns. This single capability lets them enter any nutrition category quickly.

3) The nutrition transition feels like farmer driven. More milk production means surplus fat & SNF (casien, whey , lactose) and therefore opportunity to create value added products. Every new category like whey, chocolates, drinks, cheese, creates more value for farmers. Most nutrition brands optimise for margins but they optimise for farmer income.

4) Amul is probably the only brand that simultaneously sells mass and premium products all under same brand,  same dairy and distribution and with same trust. Their products range for Rs 5 to 500. Most brands split into sub brands while Amul let the trust carry everything.

No obsession with burn, CAC ,CM1/2 growth and branding. They quietly proved that trust, scale and farmer first thinking can still beat everyone.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-11-17 06:16:21', 'relative': '2 weeks ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1763356581818}
text:
In the last few weeks, a bunch of companies went IPO and it’s a reminder that entrepreneurship can create enormous wealth for founders and their teams. But it’s also a reminder that most founders will spend years just trying to survive. Thousands are still surviving on belief, debt, delayed and no salaries. I know a few we invested in. And this is what most VCs don’t share. 

Entrepreneurship looks glamorous in hindsight but in reality, it’s years of uncertainty, low pay and stubborn belief. Till the age of 40, my average monthly salary as a founder was ~30k. Barely any savings after 15 years of building. Out of the three startups I built, one paid back moderately. Two were write offs. Only in the last two years did I see a 6 figure salary for the first time in my career.

But I’ll be honest, if you stay long enough in the game, sometimes it pays back in ways you never planned for. What I get to do now wasn’t even on my bucket list. But entrepreneurship created that pathway.

So, not every founder will ring the IPO bell or build a unicorn and that’s okay. The win isn’t always the valuation. Don’t fool yourself and build something meaningful. It will take time and it will take more out of you than you planned. It’s the resilience you build while fighting to survive that creates your pathway. 

Stay stubborn & keep building.
The world may not notice you yet.But when it finally does, it’ll act like it believed in you from day one.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-11-11 06:05:02', 'relative': '3 weeks ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1762837502431}
text:
Hey Deepinder - love seeing this and your continued interest towards health. Having met a lot of healthy food founders over the past few years and investing in a few, one big learning is people don’t want “healthy”, they want familiar food made better. 

Anything that sounds like “we’ll make you healthy” alienates the mainstream user. Parathas and Biryanis are not bad. It can be prepared in a healthier way. 

Some thoughts from our experience of working with companies in this space. 

1. Most “healthy eating” products fail because they expect the user to change habits overnight. I think there is an opportunity for Zomato to perhaps subtly nudge users. Like someone ordering a pizza at 10pm. You could suggest healthier alternatives. Don’t take away dosa, just add an option to make it with less oil.  

2. Most Indians don’t relate to quinoa and kale. They relate to better rotis, less sugar, and less fried snacks. The challenge is late dinners, long sitting hours, and irregular eating. There could be an opportunity to personalise timing and portion cues and that can do more good than macro labels.

3. People have been misled by “low fat”, “organic”, “fit” claims for years. We’ve to take a stand to show ingredient level truth & not marketing adjectives. You can enable that through your platform. 

4. Healthy options often cost 1.5–2x more, which limits repeat usage. Consumers will pay once for novelty, but daily health behaviour needs affordable habit loops.

If Zomato pulls this off right, it won’t just be a product feature but could shift public eating behaviour at scale. The real opportunity is to make healthier eating accessible and culturally relevant. That’s the hardest and most meaningful problem to solve.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-11-09 11:27:39', 'relative': '3 weeks ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1762684059266}
text:
So, Messi is coming to India and tickets to just meet him are selling for 10–95 lakh. Meanwhile, our own football league (ISL) can’t even find a bidder. That’s the paradox of Indian sports. We will worship global icons but won’t invest in local talent. This isn’t about football or Messi. It’s about our obsession with instant inspiration and seeking vanity instead building a sports culture. We scream “India should qualify for the World Cup,” but won’t watch a domestic match or build a playground in our city.

Messi will leave after three days and there will be chats in office and home for two weeks. But that’s not enough. We’ve to fix our culture and invest in playing sports and local talent.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-11-08 06:15:55', 'relative': '3 weeks ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1762578955350}
text:
Sports is for everybody and every body. Never tell yourself you can’t do it. You are never too late. That’s Shilpa, my friend and training partner. You can see the pain on her face. That’s because she’s racing the clock to get to the finish line of a marathon. She is not a professional athlete but a senior exec in her mid 40s working in a tech company. For the past 15 years of running, she had one goal. To qualify for the Boston Marathon. And in this race she had to run under 3hr 45mins to qualify for her age category.

Why am i sharing this? We’ve a narrative in our society that people working 9 to 6 are always busy. And they can’t pursue goals which are outside their life at work or home. I’ve seen Shilpa train through pain, bad weather, and fatigue with consistency and no drama. For 16 weeks of the training we did together, there were good and bad days and days of self doubt & confidence.

What’s invisible in this frame is also the tough times she had to endure mentally. Loss in family, work stress and injuries. Shilpa always had a purpose towards running. And we’d made a promise to each other- both will try to qualify for Boston. I made another promise to come back after finishing my race to cheer & run with her for the last few miles. That’s me in the picture behind her.

We all have a hidden identity in our life. Sometimes it’s an aspiration to be something we always wanted to be or the pursuit of discovering the unknown. Playing sports is life’s way of asking, how bad do you want it? And why? You can see it in her face. That’s what giving everything looks like to find the “why”.

Play sports to find your why. You’re never too late.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-10-15 07:05:44', 'relative': '1 month ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1760504744510}
text:
Some founders build something meaningful in their 20s, others in their 40s. And some take a decade to figure out what truly matters. There is no perfect timing, no rulebook that decides when you should startup and success should arrive.

Startups unfold in unpredictable ways. Some crawl for years before taking off and others find their rhythm overnight.

Let go of the pressure, comparisons, and the myth that you’re not where you’re “supposed to be.” And allow yourself to build freely without the weight of timelines and the fear that you’re too late or have missed your funding window or that your competitors are ahead.

There’s no deadline for building a company. Every founder’s pace is unique.

text:

The ones who’ll suffer most won’t be your followers or colleagues but it’ll be your kids, your partner, your parents. And of course, you. But you don’t know that yet.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-10-04 07:21:46', 'relative': '2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1759555306367}
text:

posted_at: {'date': '2025-09-26 07:31:45', 'relative': '2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1758864705632}
text:
If there’s one thing America has mastered and India hasn't, is the the art of selling a story. The American Dream was the best marketing campaign of the 20th century. They sold the American Dream so hard that the brightest talent across the world left their homes to chase it. They postured about American Dynamism until every investor believed that innovation could only happen in Silicon Valley. 

These stories gave them soft power, talent, and capital. I think India today is at a similar moment. Yes, we still wrestle with corruption, bureaucracy, and gaps in infrastructure. But so did the US in its rise. That didn’t stop them from relentlessly selling their own narrative.

What India needs now is conviction to sell the Indian Dream. To build for 1.4B people and to create confidence among our entrepreneurs and consumers that Indian products and companies  and brands are worth backing and using. There are a ton of challenges we've in health, climate, education & energy. But these are the very challenges that can create opportunities.

We should call our problems what they are -trillion dollar opportunities.

America didn’t just build companies but built stories the world wanted to believe in. If America won on story and China on scale, India must win by solving the hardest problems for the most people living in India. The media, government & investors should constantly be talking about entrepreneurs here and the Indian Dream.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-09-24 07:09:13', 'relative': '2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1758690553632}
text:

Because there are 150 million people over the age of 60 in India and most of  them are experiencing chronic health issues. While everyone is chasing Millennials and Gen Z, he chose to solve for our parents.

Btw, he's is making money, profitable and growing crazy. All without any ads or marketing. This is the kind of entrepreneurship we need more in India and should celebrate. Don’t worry about visa or AI taking your job. Solve for real problems and the opportunities in India are far bigger than you'd imagined.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-09-20 07:17:22', 'relative': '2 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1758345442067}
text:
America just put a $100,000 price tag on the Indian dream. Never been a better time than now for Indian engineers to build at home. The US was the promised land for Indian engineers but not anymore. And India isn’t the India of the 90s when engineers moved out for better pay and exposure. 

Earlier generations left India because they didn’t have a choice. Today, staying back is the smarter choice. The US is telling the world that they want fewer immigrants, at higher prices & under tighter conditions. 

In the 1960s & 70s, US actively recruited Indian doctors and engineers to fill shortages. In the 90s & 2000s, IT/software outsourcing made H-1B the obvious path for thousands of engineers. In reality, the India of today is not the India many left behind. 

This is not to say India is without its own constraints. We still have infrastructure gaps and bureaucracy is still frustrating.
But if you look back at history, Indian engineers have always thrived precisely in moments of constraint. 

The outsourcing opportunity of the 90s was born from wage arbitrage. The SaaS opportunity of the 2010s came from building global software with frugal & distributed teams. Each cycle has taken adversity and Indian entrepreneurs turned it into advantage.

The next cycle will be no different. The very inefficiencies of India around fragmented supply chains, healthcare gaps, broken education models will be the anchor to build world class companies. To solve for India is to solve for the future of other emerging markets.

This is the great inversion of our time and for the first time in history, the opportunity cost of leaving India may be greater than the opportunity cost of staying.

The last generation of Indian engineers built America’s tech backbone. The next generation has the chance to build India’s. Come back home. Time to build for India and from India.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-08-28 07:42:00', 'relative': '3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1756359720447}
text:
What’s the market for health and wellness products in India? I don’t have a right number. But here’s a way to look at this-

Herbalife & Amway does 10,000 Cr ($1B) in India every year. And mostly via multi level marketing & direct selling. No online or quick commerce.  So If foreign brands can, why can’t Indian brands do this? 

Indians are already spending 10,000 Cr a year. That’s market demand. The gap (and opportunity) is for Indian brands to fill it with genuinely good products and think differently to bring it to customers. There is a massive opportunity.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-08-20 07:21:47', 'relative': '3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1755667307799}
text:
I’ve never shared this before. We keep glamorizing entrepreneurship with stories of valuations, big exits & high salaries. But i hate to say this, for most founders the journey will look nothing like that. And you’ve to internalise this for your own mental health. 

Media will write about high salaries of unicorn founders and the 50cr apartment they bought. Many folks read this and see entrepreneurship as a gateway to quick wealth. Nothing wrong with that aspiration though. 

Till the age of 40 (in 2023), my average salary as an entrepreneur was ~30k/month. Barely had any savings across 15 years of entrepreneurship.

Did that really work out? Out of three startups, one barely paid for the five years I gave it. The other two shut down.

Only in the last 2 years did I start seeing a six figure salary for the first time in my career.

Oh, and in 2018, every bank rejected my home loan because a founder was considered a “risk profile.” I had to borrow from an NBFC at 12%.

I’m not sharing this to scare people. Just don’t let that what you read online get to your head.

Entrepreneurship looks glamorous in hindsight. In reality, it’s years of uncertainty, low pay, and stubborn belief. But if you stay long enough in the game, sometimes it pays back in ways you never imagined.

For me, what I get to do now was never part of the bucket list. But entrepreneurship created a pathway.

I read this somewhere- we need innovators, but we also need martyrs. And that’s a painful badge.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-08-14 07:15:40', 'relative': '3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1755148540758}
text:
Most AI health apps in India die because they’re over engineered & lack context . I’ve seen 100s of pitch decks and 90% won’t survive past downloads. Not because AI isn’t powerful, but founders chase the wrong use case. Sharing notes so we can build better.

1) Most copy US models built for digitized EMRs and dump it into India, where 90% of records are on paper. AI outside the doctor patient flow is useless. Clinicians are burnt out and AI must make them faster, not force them to learn another software.

2) It’s a foolish assumption to think patients will log in daily. In India, 80% patients are episodic & they show up sick & vanish when better. Retention needs habit + urgency, and you can’t build habit if your app doesn’t solve a daily pain point.

3) Everyone boasts “Our AI predicts disease before symptoms.” That’s not a feature, it’s a liability. In healthcare, trust is the product and one wrong prediction and you’ve lost it for good. Especially in a low trust market, this backfires. 

4) AI isn’t free. Most app position it like that. In a price sensitive market like India, no one will pay 500 bucks/month for “insights” when a real GP costs 500/ visit.  AI can augment, but it can’t replace human trust and follow up.

If you really want to solve for Healthcare using AI then integrate into existing healthcare touchpoints.
Make AI invisible and just make the care feel faster, cheaper, more accurate. Build trust as your moat.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-08-07 07:07:11', 'relative': '3 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1754543231724}
text:
Someone I know recently lost a family member. The medical bills crossed 20 lakh in just four weeks and only half was covered by insurance and now the family is in debt. This is the sad part of our healthcare system. If we truly want to improve quality of life in India, we must start by making healthcare accessible and affordable.

I’m not an economist, but after working with many healthcare founders, one thing is obvious that our low public health spending means poor access and families paying from their own pockets often go into debt.

Look at the numbers-India spends just 3.3% of its GDP on healthcare. In comparison: the US spends 17–20%, the UK 11%, China 7.7%, and Japan 8%. Even smaller economies like Thailand 4.3%, Vietnam 5.9% and Brazil 9.5% are ahead of us.

We lag far behind both in terms of GDP share and per capita health spending. What’s worse is, most healthcare costs in India are paid directly by households. The only way to bring balance is by significantly increasing public health spending by the government. 

We need to make primary healthcare truly universal across every city and village. Expand public health programs so no one lives in fear of hospital bills. And most importantly, regulate private healthcare to ensure price transparency, medical accountability, and protection of the poorest from predatory billing.

Affordable, accessible healthcare doesn’t just save lives. It protects families from poverty.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-07-31 07:19:56', 'relative': '4 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1753939196831}
text:
We meet dozens of startups every week that are launching AI based health apps. The pitch is always the same- “solving healthcare for a billion people.” But when you download the app, it’s mostly ChatGPT wrapped in a cute chatbot that gives generic advice. And most apps are a glorified symptom checker and an e-commerce app selling medicines , lab tests, or 10-minute doctor consults. 

I don’t understand why founders are talking  DAU, MAU or GMV. This is not really a solution to Digital Health and won’t fix anything for Indian Healthcare. 

Healthcare isn’t a SKU business. It’s not a game of faster logistics or viral acquisition. It’s about trust, clinical accuracy, and longitudinal care. None of which can be solved by just throwing venture money at marketing or pushing discount coupons on diabetes tests.

If your product doesn’t help people stay healthy, if it doesn’t build continuity of care, you’re not solving healthcare. It’s just another transactional platform. 

If you genuinely want to solve for healthcare, you’ve to understand that India’s real healthcare problems is non-communicable diseases, low doctor-to-patient ratios, Inconsistent follow-ups and zero care continuity, lack of integration between diagnostics, doctors, and data, No longitudinal health record for most citizens and poor patient literacy and trust in digital advice.

90% of Indians don’t have access to longitudinal health records, which makes continuity of care impossible.

Most Indian health apps are still consumer tech products, not health tools.

India’s healthcare crisis isn’t a UX problem. It’s a delivery and outcomes problem.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-07-18 07:03:18', 'relative': '4 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1752814998803}
text:
Every week, I get a 10 new startup pitches that says “We’ll deliver healthcare in 10 minutes.” Quick commerce is now rushing into healthcare. So I thought to do a breakdown on what’s hype and what might actually work in India. 

What could work?
1)30–60 min medicine delivery can work for chronic refills or acute needs. In metros with dense demand, it's useful. But 10-min isn’t necessary. Even same-day is fine for 90% of use cases. And honestly, your local chemist is already doing that.

2) Rapid diagnostics for home blood collection isn’t about speed but it’s about hygiene and reliability. A 2-hour sample pickup and next-morning results is a solid win. What we need is better logistics and trained phlebotomists, not faster scooters.

3)On-demand nursing or paramedic visits but for use cases like wound care, IV, injections. Could work with proper scheduling. Think “Ola for nurses,” not “Blinkit for bandages.” Needs backend infra for verification, training, EMR integration.

What won’t work (At least not now)
1) Ambulance in 10 mins sounds great until you hit Delhi or Bangalore traffic. Speed is useless without triage and location accuracy. What we really need is better coordination between hospitals and ambulance providers, not just faster wheels.

2) On-demand doctors in 10 mins is a bad idea. You don’t need any doctor fast but you need the right one. Discovery & matching are bigger problems than speed. Most video consults struggle with quality, not timing. Clinical care isn’t fast food. Trust takes time.

3) The 10-min everything app for healthcare is lazy ambition dressed up with VC money. Healthcare isn’t a SKU game but it’s complex, regulated, and hard to standardize like groceries. Great for funding buzz, terrible for trust and real outcomes.

Few thoughts if you really are passionate to build in healthcare. 
Trust > velocity.
Speed isn’t everything.
Infra & people ops > APIs.
Reliability > 10-min hacks.
Health is longitudinal & not transactional.

Good luck if you're building something in Healthcare in India.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-07-11 07:20:56', 'relative': '4 months ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1752211256331}
text:
These days, I see more and more founders sharing posts that begin with “We’ve decided to shut down our startup”. I have immense respect for every founder who says it out loud and admits something they believed in deeply didn’t work out and owns it. It takes courage.

In all these posts the most common comment is “Good luck for the next innings,” “You will bounce back,” “waiting for your comeback .” But no one is asking the founder- “How are you holding up?”

Maybe people don’t know how to ask and maybe we don’t know how to answer. Because it’s much easier to celebrate beginnings, fund raise and acquisitions. 

I didn’t realize how much of my identity was tied to the company when we shut down and i stopped getting new emails and our Discord channel was dissolved. Suddenly i no longer had a “thing” that i can say i was building. 

It took me a long time to feel new again and longer than I admitted to anyone. I felt sad, not because we failed but because I thought I was supposed to “bounce back” faster. We rarely talk about the emotional wreckage that a shutdown leaves behind. Nobody prepares you for this part. 

Maybe as an ecosystem, the next time someone says they’re shutting down, don’t rush to ask “what’s next.” Perhaps send them a direct message asking- How are they holding up and ask them if they need any help.

Sometimes, that question is the difference between someone feeling invisible and someone feeling seen. Even in the startup world, endings deserve dignity. 

And if you’ve been through it yourself, talk about it. You never know who might need to hear it.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-07-09 07:10:17', 'relative': '4 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1752037817019}
text:
Got a message yesterday from a friend that they lost their 7 day old baby last week. Got me thinking why this happens and turns out, it’s not uncommon.

India’s infant mortality rate is about 25 per 1,000 births. That’s 2.5% of infants who don’t survive. The sad part is that nearly 60% of these deaths are preventable with better care. 

This is where I believe AI in healthcare can truly make a difference. 
We can develop predictive models for at-risk pregnancies using maternal health data. Build remote monitoring systems that flag early signs of preterm labor. Even use image based diagnostics to catch neonatal infections before they turn fatal.

I hope more people building for healthcare in India focus on solutions that can detect risks early and save lives. No parent should lose a child to something we could’ve seen coming.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-06-25 07:00:27', 'relative': '5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1750827627636}
text:
I never wanted to be a VC and I never thought becoming an investor after being a founder would be this hard. 

For most of my founder journey, I got rejections. Now I sit on the other side, and I’m the one giving rejections to others. And it’s painful. Not because it’s part of the job but because I know what that rejection feels like.

Becoming a VC was never a career goal. I loved building and scraping things together. There is always a weird pleasure in that messy, glorious founder's life.

But it was one of those catchups with Nithin, when he told me- “Let’s build something that is not like a typical VC fund.” And that was my source to regain my founder high and honestly I’m still figuring this out. 

Some days, I feel like a tourist in VC. Other days, I feel like I’m helping create something from scratch. That paradox somehow lives in me every day. I told Nithin the same- I’d rather be known for what I build than what I fund. That’s why my bio still says entrepreneur and not VC. Somehow I still can’t fully relate to that title. 

Nithin’s trust to build something that doesn’t exist gave me permission to see Rainmatter by Zerodha differently. Not just a fund but a place we’re building with founders at the center. Even the ones we don’t invest in. This feels like being an investor with a founder’s soul. 

I’ve started to realize my role now is to be useful. To cheer for entrepreneurs and to show up sometimes with capital, but often just with time, empathy, and perspective. Sometimes it's reminding someone that their health matters more than their next funding round. And sometimes, it's okay with not having a perfect answer.

All I know is- I still want to build. Even if what I’m building now isn’t a product. It’s an ecosystem. And that’s enough for today. 

I'm writing all of this, first for my own mental clarity. And also to be honest with all the founders who reach out to me, and the other people who ask me for career advice.

I don’t have a grand vision of what this role should be. It’s evolving. Slowly. And maybe that’s the point. Not every journey needs a playbook.

You may be a founder, someone working in a startup or building things at a large company. If you’re confused about your career, it's ok. 

I still don’t have all the answers yet. I’m still becoming.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-06-09 07:22:00', 'relative': '5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1749446520106}
text:
Doctors in India die earlier than their patients. I know it sounds crude but what it means is Indian doctors have a life expectancy that’s nearly 10 years shorter than the average Indian. And this is reported by Indian Medical Association. 

The primary causes are Cardiovascular disease and infections. Ironically, the very things they work tirelessly to prevent.

Endure 10-12 years of medical education with the only aspiration to save lives but be at the receiving end of stress, anxiety, and long working hours. And be a part of a system that doesn’t give them time to care for their own health. The average Indian doctor clocks 60–80 hours a week and approx 300-400 doctors die by suicide every year. Mostly because of the impossible expectations they carry. It takes 10+ years of study before a doctor sees their first salary.

They’re taught that saving lives is everything. After 10hrs+ of work, you can then go and figure your own personal health & family life. And after all this, they’re now told that AI will make them obsolete. That their jobs will be replaced by software tools because the system is inefficient.

I meet atleast 50 companies a month that pitch AI solutions for healthcare. These tools matter and they can make processes faster and improve accessibility. No doubt Indian healthcare needs better processes and better tech. But what it needs more than anything is empathy.

India’s hospitals are crowded and the health crisis is real. But what’s also been ignored is the mental and physical health of our doctors & medical staff. 

This isn’t a rant against technology, AI or healthcare system. But a reminder to self and maybe a few who are reading this that without empathy and without recognizing the human cost, there will be no healthcare system left.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-06-08 07:19:21', 'relative': '5 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1749359961477}
text:
An advice from one entrepreneur to another thinking to become a founder today. Manifest this reality-it’s going to be hard. Harder than you imagine. Blogs and YouTube videos are designed to make you feel good. They’re useful, but they’re mostly made by people who seen some form of success. Don’t start thinking there’s a single linear path. The journey will be be scary and lonely.

Take care of your health, both physical and mental. Walk, run, meditate, lift, cycle, swim. Just do anything. Don’t wait for a crisis. There’s no pivot for your body.

Don’t take your relationships for granted. You think they’ll wait, but they won’t. And they shouldn't.  Everyone has finite time to build a life. You’re not wealthy if you have no one to share it with.

Lastly, don’t chase status. It’s the surest way to damage your joy and clarity. Every mistake is an opportunity to improvise. Get good at being corrected without being offended. The rest will follow if you build from a place of authenticity and love for the craft.

These aren’t daily wage workers but young & educated with smartphones, fandom merch, and the physical energy to stand for hours on road and make video reels. Btw, 14% of our youth are unemployed today. 

Same happens when a new Apple store opens. Thousands gather, not to buy, but to show their desires a belonging.

Sometimes I think the food and 10min delivery companies have done more to keep the social order than any policy.
Delivery boys & riders have found work. They’ve a reason to show up, even if it’s not perfect. Imagine if they didn’t have that work.

30% of India is under the age of 29 today: When the youth can’t find meaning in work, they’ll seek it in crowds, in fandoms and in shallow status games.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-05-29 07:29:21', 'relative': '6 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1748496561253}
text:
There is enough evidence of reckless school bus driving in India. It’s 2025 and we are still looking away. Every morning, I see a few school bus going the wrong way against traffic just to save a few 100 meters. The buses are packed with children and parents are standing by, smiling and waving goodbye as if nothing’s wrong.

I’m sure this is common across cities and schools including the so-called elite ones.

We want our kids to learn coding at 5, speak three languages, and use the latest gadgets. But we are comfortably ignoring road safety and not questioning the system that lets an unsupervised driver gamble with kids lives every day. 

If you’re a parent, your biggest responsibility is to ask your school to install a dash cam on every school bus and share a feed to you everyday. There is tech to detect rash driving. You’ve to ask the schools to use systems that track, record, and report unsafe behaviour.  

If you witness a reckless school bus driver, take a photo or video of the incident, capture the bus number and report the incident to the school immediately. Educate your kids on what’s unsafe and how to report it to teachers & parents without fear.

If an action is not taken by the school, gather support from other parents and file a complaint with the local police and RTO. Reckless school drivers should be jailed. 

Just don’t stay silent. One firm parent can set off a chain of accountability. When tragedy happens, we blame everyone. There is no point doing that when we can avoid it. Don’t let ignorance be the reason your child gets hurt.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-05-27 07:20:58', 'relative': '6 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1748323258222}
text:
There are a few investors who have turned startups into status games. I’ve held back on saying this for a while but it needs to be called out. They will host events only for IIT/IIM founders. Some call it a mixer, but invite only unicorn founders and flaunt selfie pics with them. 

I’ve nothing against IIT/IIM or unicorn founders. Most are smart entrepreneurs. But the job of VCs is to help create an ecosystem regardless of the pedigree. Creating exclusive clubs and playing these popularity games is the worst status games to play in entrepreneurship. 

I was a founder with no pedigree. So when I see startup events filtered by tags, I know exactly who gets left out. It’s the same kind of founders who are already battling self doubt, limited visibility and zero access.

This is exactly what happened in the job market 10 years back. Most job descriptions asked for IIT & IIM degree- even if the role had nothing to do with it.
And we lost a whole generation of talent to that lazy filter.

As a society we’ve mistaken proximity for potential. And that’s a dangerous filter for India that is trying to build its identity to value innovation.

If you are a founder- don’t waste time trying to get into rooms built on pedigree.
Build something so real, they have no choice but to knock on your door. Your worth isn’t defined by where you come from, but by what you create.

text:

People often ask why we cheer and share about startups we haven’t invested in. It’s because we are not just investors, we’re here to build ecosystems. And India needs that now.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-05-17 07:04:47', 'relative': '6 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1747458287517}
text:
I know someone who worked for one of the world’s biggest tech companies. Almost 20 years of loyalty and last week was laid off. He is a brilliant engineer who showed up every day and solved some of the hardest engineering problems. Mentored tons of juniors and fixed bugs that saved millions. 

Last week, an email decided his time was up. Because a new AI tool is now optimising for internal cost.

I’ve been saying this to everyone around me, the world doesn’t reward loyalty. It rewards leverage. If you’re quietly building, chances are you’re quietly disposable too. Wether you are a founder, employee or just anyone. 

I don’t say this to be cynical. I say this so we stop waiting for the system to be fair. It won’t be. Work is no longer a family, it’s a market. You are not being exploited but being priced. The system isn’t cruel, it’s just indifferent. This might sound cold but is the reality. Stop expecting fairness from systems and start designing freedom for yourself.

So build leverage, build relationships build your voice. Build equity in something that can’t be taken away in a reorg. And above all, build something that doesn’t require someone else’s permission to keep you going.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-05-08 07:33:12', 'relative': '6 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1746682392571}
text:
The top 5 sports brands in India generate 12,000+ crore in revenue and not one is homegrown. In a country with 700M under age of 30 & a growing fitness culture, no Indian brand has even a modest share. Some of our companies work with these global brands. Here’s what I’ve learnt.

1)Nike, Adidas & Puma sell aspiration that makes you feel like an athlete before you become one. Decathlon cracked India with trust & access. No celebs, just quality at honest prices. It's where middle class families discover sport. That's how habits & loyalty are built.

2) Most Indian brands sell athleisure, not performance. They look good but fail under stress, no real R&D, no athlete testing. They sell products, not belonging. No community building, no running clubs, no athlete support. That’s where global brands pull ahead.

3) Indian brands chase influencers and Instagram aesthetics, but lack consistency, offline presence, distribution and category focus. Sports is tactile & people want to try products before buying. Global brands win with retail, experience, and trust. Indian brands stay stuck online.

How does Indian consumer think? 
1) Indian consumers are price-conscious, but not at the cost of aspiration. They’ll skip a local ₹2,000 shoe and instead save up for a Nike or Puma at ₹6000+ because global brands offer trust and status. Price alone doesn’t win, perceived value and brand story matter more.

2) Most Indian brands still design with a male first lens but urban women shop more for running, yoga and fitness. If you ignore them you miss the fastest-growing segment. The average Indian buyer choose safe & established over new and edgy.

Indian brands sell sportswear but global brands build sport culture. I think if you can make performance cool, communities visible, and quality obvious. There’s a real shot at the pie. But it won’t be quick. You’ll have to play the long game.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-05-06 07:17:00', 'relative': '6 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1746508620816}
text:
I’ve been a founder for ten years, and an investor for the last two. Having been on both sides of the table, I wish more people spoke openly about two truths that haven’t changed over the years. First-entrepreneurship is still scary. Second-raising money won’t save you from that fear.

In the beginning when you starting up, you will be scared of whether the idea will work. As you grow, you will be scared of losing what you've built. And at scale, you will be scared of irrelevance, competition, and the weight of expectations. 

If someone tells you, “It’s only scary in the early days”, they’re either lying, lucky, or haven’t been through enough cycles. Fear is not a phase. It’s part of the job.

There’s no safety net. No sabbatical. No social security in entrepreneurship. So, step one is accepting the fear. Don’t wait for it to go away. It won’t. Learn to operate with it. 

And then if you think raising money will solve your fear. It will not. In fact, funding often will add more fear. Now you're accountable because you have burn. And your decisions are being watched, measured, and judged.  You’re not just building a company but managing other people’s money, expectations, and reputations. Money will buy you time, not peace. 

If you're building something right now and you're scared, its good. It means you're alive to what matters. Just don’t let the fear fool you into thinking you’re not ready. The fear doesn’t go away. But with time, you get better at walking with it.

The world may not see you yet. But you’re already doing the hardest part of showing up despite the fear. And that’s what founders are made of.
Good luck friends!

posted_at: {'date': '2025-04-29 07:31:14', 'relative': '7 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1745904674123}
text:
Hospitals are the only profitable healthcare businesses in India. Top 5 hospitals made 47000 crore in revenue last year. Startup founders building in health can learn more from studying a hospital business than downloading health apps of their competitors. 

Hospitals win because they control the full stack: diagnosis, treatment, follow-up. They have built-in distribution via doctors & insurance. And they’re anchored in trust. Preventive health in India still sells vitamins, not outcomes. There is high churn & zero trust.

If you’re building a preventive health startup, work on these first principles:

1) Own outcomes not engagement. Show real wins like weight lost, BP controlled, diabetes reversed. Hospitals thrive because people must act. Nobody forgets a surgery. Everyone forgets a health checkup.

2) Indians don’t trust digital care. They trust doctors, nurses, buildings they can walk into. Startups must build local trust, not just national scale. People follow health advice from someone they trust around them. Think clinics, coaches, phlebotomists not faceless dashboards.

3) Anchor your business to real pain. Not aspirational health. Reframe prevention as pre-crisis management, not “wellness.” 

4) Make it hard to churn. Hospitals don’t need retention teams but patients come back because they must. Can you build the same emotional gravity?

5) Bundle services like hospitals do. Diagnosis + protocol + human handholding = retention. Sell the whole experience, not one off lab tests or consults. Most apps offer “lifestyle programs” with no human involvement, and 80% drop-off in 90 days.

What hospitals can’t do? They can’t be proactive, scalable, or delightful. They're stuck in reactive, bloated models. There is an opportunity for startup founders to build “digital hospitals for the 90%” that is preventive, distributed, affordable, and habit-forming.

The Indian preventive health market won’t be won by better UI. It’ll be won by startups that behave like digital hospitals: trusted, accountable, painful to leave. You’re not fighting apathy, you’re fighting the absence of urgency.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-04-22 07:07:17', 'relative': '7 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1745298437578}
text:
Big fan of what Y Combinator has done for founders. But I’ve never understood the obsession with building a YC equivalent in India by investors here. I’m convinced it will never happen. Not because we lack talent or ambition, but because YC wasn’t just a structure. It was the outcome of a rare mix of time, place, and cultural defaults.

YC emerged in a place where risk was cheap, talent was abundant, trust was a default & failure was celebrated as a credential. India has almost none of those ingredients in the same proportion yet.

Indian founders are world class at surviving, hacking & stretching resources. But YC worked because it taught founders to focus on scaling instead of surviving.
Indian early stage capital still acts like it's lending money , not taking risk. Even seed rounds come with board seats and monthly reporting. 

The genius of YC was its narrative monopoly. They created status & not just capital. India’s status economy works differently. You can’t manufacture prestige in India without a IIT, IIM next to your name.

India won’t have its YC. But maybe that’s a good thing. 
What we need in India is founder first micro VCs with real skin in the game. A media and narrative engine that spotlights Indian builders solving Indian and world problems from India.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-04-21 07:25:33', 'relative': '7 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1745213133407}
text:
Because we invest in healthcare, I get this question all the time: Will AI replace doctors? As a technology optimist I don’t claim to have all the answers. But i feel this question usually reveals how little we understand both about AI & healthcare.

When people say AI will replace doctors and teachers in the next decade. They  assume that intelligence is enough to make an impact and forgets that trust is the real currency in both healthcare and education.

Doctors don’t just prescribe, they hold your hand during a cancer diagnosis. Teachers don’t just deliver content but they spot the kid falling behind, build confidence, and unlock potential. AI can assist, but it can’t replace human empathy and trust.

So is AI important? Absolutely.
AI can read scans better than most radiologists. It can solve for homework & personalise lessons faster than a teacher. It can democratize access to world class knowledge, in any language, at near zero cost.

But can it replace the human relationship that sits at the core of these professions? AI doesn’t replace doctors. It replaces inefficiencies around them. Likewise AI won’t replace teachers. But it can free them from admin so they can actually teach

Tech is best when it’s invisible. When it supports human work & not erase it.
Yes, AI will change healthcare & education. The goal of AI shouldn't be to replace doctors & teachers. It’s to make a billion people feel like they finally have one. That’s the real opportunity & that’s where the best builders will focus i feel.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-04-18 07:13:20', 'relative': '7 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1744953200812}
text:
There’s a massive untapped opportunity to build a healthy quick service restaurant (QSR) business in India. But most have failed to scale. We’ve evaluated several for investment. Here’s a breakdown of why the model hasn’t worked yet & and what it’ll take to make it work. 

Indians are becoming more health conscious, cities are growing, incomes are rising. Yet every “healthy” QSR has failed to scale. Why? Because health is a feature, not a category. QSRs thrive on habit, indulgence & price. Three things health food companies struggles with.

1) Healthy QSRs struggle in India because most consumers won’t pay a premium for “healthy.” Health is an aspiration, not a necessity. Why spend ₹300 on a salad when you can get a filling biryani or dosa for half the price? Value beats virtue every time.

2) Healthy food ≠ crave worthy food. QSRs win by hitting the bliss point-fat, sugar, salt. Burgers & biryanis trigger dopamine, millet bowls don’t. A cheesy pizza will always beat a quinoa salad in a taste war. Cravings drive repeat orders. Not calories.

3) Indian palates are habit-driven. Most eat the same 4–5 dishes weekly. Healthy QSRs fail when they push alien formats like quinoa bowls, lettuce wraps, hummus. They feel expensive, unfamiliar, and inconvenient. If it doesn’t fit the habit, it won’t scale

4) Operational costs and unit economics don’t scale. Quality inputs cost more, wastage is higher & margins are thin. Without high margin add-ons like sodas and fries, balancing profit is tough

5) In India, food is emotional comfort, not a guilt trip. Parathas, vada pav, jalebis bring joy. But most healthy QSRs feel like a scolding parent, not a treat. One sells discipline, the other sells happiness

Subway has 900+ outlets in India with just one hero product- their sandwich. If that can scale, there’s room to build a better, healthier QSR. After speaking to founders who scaled or shut down, here are some thoughts on what it’ll take for a healthy QSR to work in India

1) Sell delicious first, healthy second. QSRs thrive on cravings, not morality. No one buys “keto wraps”, they buy a butter chicken roll that tastes amazing (and happens to be healthy). Flavor wins. Health should be invisible, not the pitch

2) Integrate into existing food habits. Forget quinoa bowls. Make millet biryanis. Forget lettuce wraps. Make chapati tacos. You must must disguise health inside familiar food formats

3) Be affordable at scale. ₹400 won’t scale. ₹99–₹199 is the sweet spot.

4) Solve for convenience, not just health. People will pay for speed & ease. If a healthy QSR takes longer than McDonald's or Zomato delivery, it won't work.

5) Start with Gen Z & millennials. They don’t cook, care about fitness & crave social validation for eating well.

A healthy QSR can work in India, if it stops preaching & starts entertaining. The winner won’t be the most nutritious, but the one that makes healthy food fun, tasty & affordable that people don’t even realize they’re eating right.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-04-16 07:29:33', 'relative': '7 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1744781373257}
text:
In the last five years, over ₹2 lakh crore has been lost to corporate frauds that includes high profile startups. Btw, financial fraud isn't a new phenomenon. It's as old as ambition itself. But when company leaders commit fraud, it's the employees who bear the brunt of losing jobs, financial security, and years of hard work.

Investors can write off their losses as part of risk capital but you as employees risk your most valuable asset- time and trust. Your company's culture code will scream about transparency but that doesn't mean anything if you don't get access to financial health of the company.

The only way to safeguard your professional career is to stay vigilant. The most basic you can do it to build your own financial literacy by understanding the company's profit & loss statement and balance sheet.  

In India, regardless of whether a company is public or private, organizations are mandated to file their financials with the Ministry of Corporate Affairs (MCA). Anyone can access these records through the MCA portal. You as an employee must cultivate the financial understanding of your company beyond vanity metrics and be prepared to act when red flags arise.

If you're not the owner, you're the product.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-04-14 07:28:42', 'relative': '7 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1744608522010}
text:
Met a founder last week, a computer science grad from Berkeley who chose to return to India and build an AI tool for children with speech disorders. He could’ve stayed back, joined Big Tech, and lived comfortably in the US. Instead, he came home to solve a deeply human problem from India, for the world.

Why? Because 3-5% of children globally are affected by stuttering and often face bullying and emotional isolation. It doesn’t just delay speech but impacts their confidence, identity, and the entire childhood. Speech is how we connect, express needs, and feel seen.

This is the kind of ambition and first-principles thinking often missing in the loud “Are Indian startups as good as US or China?” debate. These founders don’t chase headlines and mainstream media rarely writes about them. But they’re quietly shaping a new narrative for Indian startups.

Because building for real pain is harder than building for scale or valuation. And that’s exactly where India will win.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-04-07 08:07:59', 'relative': '7 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1744006079694}
text:
Today is World Health Day. Your HR will schedule team activities and your CEO will post about wellness being a core value. Brands will send you discount codes to remind you to eat clean and stay fit.

Everyone will try to sell you an ideal world but no one really knows what you're going through. Being stuck in a 9 to 6 cycle, drowning in meetings, commuting for hours, and worrying about not being there for family. That’s the real health hazard. You already know health is important but it just doesn’t take priority in your chaotic daily life. I used to be that person. Always busy, always postponing and that ignorance cost me a lot. Both professionally & personally.

You just need to do something and do it consistently. Exercise, meditation, walk, sleep, eat clean, play & family. Go to therapy if you need to. Ignore what’s trending. All this longevity talk and health podcasts are of no good if you can't do simple basics.  

Remember when you go back home tonight, your child or your parent won’t care how many meetings you had, how long you were stuck in traffic, or how crazy your inbox looked. All they want is your undivided attention.

The people who love you aren’t asking for a six-pack. They’re asking for your presence. Stay healthy not to impress the world, but to be there for the ones who matter.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-04-04 10:48:08', 'relative': '8 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1743756488542}
text:
India was once called a nation of call centers and it sounded like an insult. But quietly, it trained millions of young Indians to speak fluent English and dream beyond their hometowns. That was phase one.

Then we became the IT back office of the world. And it created a generation of engineers who could write  code, manage complex systems, and deliver at global scale. That was phase two.

Today, we’re in phase three. Indian startups are solving for India and it looks chaotic from the outside. These are signs of a country solving its own problems first, before solving the world’s.

Sure, we should go more deep tech and we will i think. But first we need more patient capital, more research led universities & more talent density. Deep tech ecosystem can't be built in a hackathon. It will be built by million engineers who get obsessed in solving billion daily problems.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-04-02 07:39:14', 'relative': '8 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1743572354183}
text:
When I was a founder, no one replied to my emails or returned calls. Now I'm an investor and everyone wants to meet me. This is a side of entrepreneurship no one talks about. I've been meaning to share these thoughts for a while now. 

As a founder, I would reach out to investors, potential hires, partners and all kind of people. Mostly sending cold emails and begging for warm intros. Some days I’d open my inbox ten times an hour. Nothing. Not even a polite No. And every meeting I did get felt like charity. People would check their phones while I was passionately talking about what i'm building. It wasn’t just isolation, it felt being invisible & lonely. 

People say “build in public,” but the truth is, unless you’ve raised a lot of money or built a network around the big entrepreneur circle, you’re just noise in the feed. No one roots for you unless the world already has.

No one talks about this version of entrepreneurship where your startup is still ugly and half working. People don’t really meet founders. They meet press releases. Funding headlines. Vanity metrics. You don’t exist until TechCrunch or Yourstory says you do.

I didn’t have time for personal branding. I was too busy building, selling and surviving. And most days i'll wake up wondering , am I building something real and useful? 

Then I became an investor. Suddenly, I was interesting.
Now my inbox is overflowing. Everyone wants to meet me. Founders, operators, influencers, even the ones who never replied before. 

I get a lot of engagement on my posts & people tag me on social media. People ask for advice & feedback. They send decks, DMs & invite me as a guest to their events. Same events where i couldn't get entry earlier as a founder.  Irony is, I used to be ignored for building. Now I’m celebrated for betting. 

This is the part that messes with your head. Not the rejection but how conditional the world’s attention really is. So now, I try to reply to every cold email. I take the calls that don’t scale. Because I know what it’s like to be building something real and feel completely invisible.

If you’re a founder in the trenches, just remember this. This world doesn’t reward quiet builders. It rewards loud signals. And when you're not seen, it eats away at your mental health. Not because you're weak. But because being human means wanting to be heard.  And if you’re on the other side, pause before you ignore the next unknown builder. Because today's nobody might be tomorrow's someone. And they’ll remember who replied.

Keep going.
The world may not meet you yet.
But one day, it will pretend it always did.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-03-28 06:30:37', 'relative': '8 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1743139837431}
text:
India has 150 million+ people above the age 60 and there is a massive opportunity to keep them healthy & fit. But everyone’s focused on Gen Z and no one’s building for their parents. It’s a hard business but a big one. We’ve invested in two companies. Here’s why it’s tough and how one should crack it.

Understand the reality first.
1. Elders don’t think of “health” as proactive. They’re conditioned to wait until something breaks before acting. You’re selling a solution to a problem they don’t know they have yet.

2. The 65-year-old needs it but their 35-year-old child pays for it.
You're not selling to the elder. You’re selling to their guilt-driven kids in Gurgaon or US. The buyer ≠ the user.

3. Trust is everything and you don’t have it.
Indian elders trust: Their doctor, astrologer & their neighbour
Not apps. Not tech bros. Not AI. You can't growth hack trust. You earn it slowly, locally.

4. They don’t want new habits. They’ve had the same breakfast for 40 years.
You’re not selling a product. You’re undoing decades of routine.

5. Distribution is hyperlocal. Elders don’t click Insta ads. They talk to the uncle in their colony. You scale building by building not by user cohorts.

Yes, 150M+ elders. But it’s not one market. It’s a thousand tiny tribes.
Different languages, cultures, food habits, family structures, and tech comfort levels. If it were easy, Tata or Reliance would’ve done it already. But it’s wide open now. The one who combines tech + trust + real care will win.

So how do you crack it?

1. Think first principles & not trends
 Don’t build a “senior fitness app.”  Ask: Why did they stop moving? What gives them joy? You’re selling independence, not health.

2. Design for peace, not features. One-click help, One daily routine, One trusted face. Great elder products feel like human care not software.

3. Human-first, tech-enable.  Don’t replace the daughter. Support her. Train 100 amazing elder coaches. Build tools to help them scale.

4. Don't focus on CAC. Here, it’s about trust per acquisition.  You’re not selling toothpaste. You’re asking to be let into their daily life. Start offline. Build trust then tech.

5. You’re in the business of habit change & not selling an app or a pill.
Get them to walk 15 minutes a day. Add protein to breakfast. Laugh more. Sleep better. Small wins compound. Don’t build for scale first. Build for consistency. 
 Be in the business of habit change. 

6. This isn’t a hackable D2C play. It’s a decade-long trust business. Build for one community. Get to know 100 elders by name. Solve deep, boring problems with elegance. 

Everyone’s chasing the next billion youth users. But the hidden opportunity lies in serving the first 150 million elders.  The elder care market in India isn’t just underserved. It’s misunderstood and needs long-term play. Founders who crack this will build generational companies.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-03-25 06:14:49', 'relative': '8 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1742879689255}
text:
In the last decade, over 50+ telemedicine startups in India raised more than $2 billion and most have shut down. The pitch was- India has too few doctors, too many patients, and a broken healthcare system. Technology would fix it. But it didn’t. Here’s a breakdown. 

Startups and investors saw telemedicine as a Silicon Valley playbook that can be forced onto India’s complex healthcare reality. It was always an overrated idea because it fundamentally misunderstood how healthcare actually works in India. Let me explain.

#1 India’s healthcare is built on trust, not tech. The local doctor is a family confidant, not just a provider. People prefer seeing a doctor in person, even if it means waiting in long queues. They don’t trust prescriptions from an anonymous screen. In India, healthcare is about relationships, not transactions.

#2 Telemedicine starts in the wrong place i.e talking to a doctor. But in India, healthcare begins with a test. Diagnosis comes first, then treatment. A video call can only advise a test, but the patient still needs a clinic visit. But why would the patient pay for an online consultation when they have to visit a physical clinic anyway? Healthcare is driven by diagnostics, not just consultations.

#3 Healthcare in India is a family decision, not an individual one. A 60-year-old man with a fever isn’t booking a telemedicine consult but his family takes him to a doctor. People want reassurance, not a chatbot or a pixelated video call. Telemedicine assumed individuals would seek care alone, but that’s not how India works.

#4 Telemedicine aimed to solve "access to healthcare," but India’s real issue is access to quality care. Government hospitals lack trust, private clinics are costly, and random doctors on an app don’t inspire trust. In rural areas, people prefer the village doctor or pharmacist hey feel accountable in a way apps never could.

#5 Telemedicine focused on one-time issues like fever or cough, but India’s real problem is chronic diseases like diabetes, hypertension, heart disease. These need ongoing care, not quick doctor chats. No diabetic wants to "chat with a bot" about sugar levels, they need a plan, a trusted doctor, and in-person care. Prescription is the real currency.

#6 Most doctors in India were skeptical of telemedicine from the start. Not because they are anti tech, but because they don’t want legal liability for a patient they have never physically examined. If a misdiagnosis happens over video call, who is responsible? The doctor, the platform or the hospital? There were no clear answers and most experienced doctors don't want to risk their reputation.

If you're an entrepreneur building in healthcare, don’t chase convenience or optimize for speed. Build trust & optimize for quality care. I've written more elaborate notes on each of these points. Check the comments section.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-03-23 06:20:45', 'relative': '8 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1742707245531}
text:
Last week, I overheard a man casually tell his wife, “Tum gym jaa kar kya karogi”. This is a person who is well educated and seemingly progressive. 

Just celebrating one women’s day in a year doesn’t do any good. We’ve to change this assumption in our society that physical exercise and sports aren’t really meant for women. And lifting weights will make them look weird and fitness for women is about looking lean, not stronger.

If you walk into most gyms, you’ll find the space is still dominated by men. An outdoor run is still a luxury for most women in India even today since safety is a concern every time someone steps out. 

We need to educate women and men that strength training is not just safe for women but it’s essential.

A recent study reports that women get 20% less physical activity per week than men and they face the highest inactivity levels, with 33% failing to meet WHO guidelines. 

One of the topics we’ve been thinking at Rainmatter is how we can create more safe spaces for women to get physical movement without the fear of being judged. 

We need to build safe spaces and an ecosystem where women train & move without fear, without judgment and without needing permission.

This is why we partnered with Swetha Subbiah & Tanvie Hans and backed Sisters in Sweat, a fitness and sports community designed for women, by women.

Supporting initiatives like Sisters in Sweat is just the start. The real change happens when we shift mindsets where every woman feels empowered to move. Every woman deserves the right to play a sport, run and feel strong without judgment and without asking for permission.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-03-19 06:11:48', 'relative': '8 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1742361108694}
text:
Everyone today loves this grand narrative that "Tech will fix everything". Every week a news article or investor confidently declares that tech will fix healthcare & most entrepreneurs fall for this illusion of disruption. This narrative is doing more harm than good.

Most entrepreneurs today think, if we can build a beautifully designed app, use AI to chat, automate doctor-patient interactions, and scale it to millions of users, we can "solve" healthcare. 

It sounds great in a pitch deck. It almost never works in reality.

Why? Because healthcare isn't e-commerce. You can’t scale a hospital bed like a food delivery fleet. You can’t disrupt chronic disease with a better UI. You can’t solve trust with a chatbot. Healthcare isn’t a transaction, it’s a relationship.

If you're serious about fixing healthcare, start thinking from first principles.

Everyone wants to build the “Uber of Healthcare.” But Uber works because a ride from point A to B is a simple transaction. Healthcare isn’t. You can’t just match a patient with a doctor and assume the job is done. Don't build a generic doctor consultation app with a new UI or a marketplace that lists thousand doctor names. Focus on depth of care, outcomes, and follow-up treatments before chasing millions of users. Build a connected system that only focuses on driving outcomes.

Don't over focus on AI without fixing the basics. AI can help a doctor diagnose faster. But it can’t replace the doctor. Yet, doctors alone won’t solve India’s healthcare crisis. They also need trained frontline workers assisted by smart tech. Build AI tools to assist doctors enable faster diagnoses. Don't oversell your AI engine or LLM models to a patient. 

It doesn’t matter if we have the best doctor or AI engine if the right medicine isn’t available. Up to 20% of medicines sold in India are fake or substandard. Counterfeit drugs are a massive problem & the Pharma companies are growing this $58 billion market. Perhaps a great usecase to use AI and tech to streamline the supply chain. 

So, can tech fix healthcare? Yes. 
But not by replacing doctors, hospitals, or traditional care systems. The biggest healthcare opportunities in India are not about disruption but augmentation.

Tech alone won’t fix Indian healthcare. But finding the right places to apply can make a 10x difference. Healthcare isn’t an industry that gets "disrupted" overnight. But it can be upgraded piece by piece, solving for what really matters. And if you understand that, you’ll build something that actually works.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-03-17 06:20:09', 'relative': '8 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1742188809464}
text:
India’s protein market is booming but not in the way brands expect. As investors who’ve backed 10 different protein companies across various form factors, we’ve had front-row seats to what’s scaling well and setting cash on fire. Sharing some observations here.

#1 There is some adoption to protein chocolates, wafers, and ready-to-drink beverages because they align with Indian eating habits. Indians snack, they don’t ‘supplement.’ You’ve to continuously prioritise taste over macros. Companies that market protein as an everyday indulgence rather than a rigid health choice gets customer attention. 

#2 Whey Protein is still the king due to consumer trust, but the buyer has evolved. The ‘gym bro’ audience is now joined by professionals, homemakers, and teenagers who want overall health. Companies are now positioning whey as a ‘daily wellness’ product rather than a muscle-building tool. Whey still has the highest consumer trust and branding built over a decade.

#3 Plant or alternative protein needs more time for mass adoption. Unlike the West, India’s plant-based movement is not driven by ethics but by affordability and digestion concerns. Soy protein struggles with misinformation and pea protein is expensive. If you are a company in this space, maybe sell vegan protein as a ‘premium’ alternative to whey, rather than a ‘digestive-friendly’ option.

#4 Indians think in meals, not macros. Global protein brands emphasize grams per serving. But Indians look for complete meals. You will therefore see entry of high-protein paneer, rotis & dosa mix formats.

#5 Indians want taste first, nutrition second. In the West, function comes first. In India, taste dictates repeat purchases. Lower protein content per serving, but higher frequency of purchase. Brands that localize flavors (kesar badam, mango lassi, Thandai) get more customer attention. 

#6 Western brands lean on clinical studies. Indians trust Ayurveda and generational wisdom. The smart brands use both. 

India’s protein market isn’t a western import—it’s a local adaptation challenge. The companies that figure this out will dominate. The rest will keep burning capital trying to change consumer behavior that isn’t shifting anytime soon.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-03-13 06:10:24', 'relative': '8 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1741842624116}
text:
We've evaluated 50+ mental health apps for investments and I personally used 20+ products. None of them delivered meaningful results. The problem isn’t technology but the assumption that therapy is just pattern recognition & that AI can replace human presence. Here's a breakdown. 

#1 There is lack of emotional intelligence in the current AI models that are only designed to simulate conversation. But therapy is more than words. It’s about trust, micro-expressions, and intuitive emotional calibration—things AI still struggles with. Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT and others can generate empathetic responses, but they don’t “feel” anything. They simulate and patients know the difference. 

#2 There is a large cultural and linguistic barriers in Indian context. Most AI models are trained in western psychological frameworks. Mental health challenges in India are unlike other cultures -societal expectations, family structures, and stigma. An AI chatbot trained on CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy) modules from Western research and university doesn't understand the pressure of an arranged marriage or parental expectations in an IIT-obsessed household.

#3 Most mental health apps claim to be “personalized.” In reality, they offer generic suggestions based on symptom checklists. Real therapists go beyond checklists. They adapt in real time &  modify their approach dynamically. AI, despite all its advancements, still struggles with this level of nuanced adaptability.

Some thoughts how AI in Mental Health could actually work. 

#1 A good starting point is when AI supports therapists, not replace them. Imagine a model that helps analyze past therapy sessions and provide therapists with structured insights on patient progress. Instead of AI replacing human interaction, it should act as a co-pilot that enhances therapy effectiveness.

#2 AI is fantastic at pattern recognition. We could use it to identify early warning signs of mental health deterioration by analyzing speech patterns, writing styles, and biometric data. Maybe hand over the interpretation and intervention to a real human therapist who can act on this data.

#3 Mental health AI models need training data that reflect the Indian psyche. Solutions should be developed with inputs from Indian psychologists, using regional languages and culturally relevant therapy approaches. An AI that understands the shame associated with divorce in India or the anxiety induced by societal expectations will be far more effective.

The future of AI in mental health isn’t about replacing therapists; it’s about amplifying human connection. 

Founders building in mental health should focus on integrating AI where it excels (data analytics, early diagnostics, and habit formation) while keeping humans where they matter most (trust, deep healing, and emotional intuition).

AI in mental health isn’t about AI being human. It’s about AI making humans better. That’s where the real opportunity lies.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-03-11 06:14:10', 'relative': '8 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1741670050935}

India produces 1.5 million engineering graduates every year. Only 15-30% are employable. Another argument is we don’t need 1.5 million engineering clones, we need a handful of curious thinkers who find pleasure in the joy of figuring things out.

If we focus on creating an environment where young minds can ask questions, tinker, and explore without fear of failure, the outliers will emerge naturally.

Maybe stop mass-producing degrees and start incubating curiosity? Also, telling students to “be curious” won’t work unless curiosity leads to clear rewards- better career opportunities, more creative freedom, or direct financial upside. If societal pressures (family expectations, fear of failure, etc.) still reward safe paths, many won’t take the risk of exploring outlier territory. If curiosity won’t pay the bills, safety will always win.

Don’t wait for burnout to force a reset—build a life where your mental and physical health supports you. Work should fuel your life, not consume it.
