posted_at: {'date': '2025-03-05 06:39:29', 'relative': '9 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1741153169123}
text:
If you’ve spent enough time in the tech industry, you’ll notice a growing trend-people are more focused on building narratives than companies. And the favourite one is declaring their city as the tech capital of India.
Bangalore is the “Tech Capital.” , Delhi is the “IPO Capital.”, Mumbai is the “Fintech Capital.” , Chennai is “SaaS Capital.”

But has anyone ever fought over being the sports capital of India? No- because talent emerges from everywhere. There’s no single agriculture or manufacturing capital either.

We should collectively move past this obsession with crowning a single tech hub. Instead of fighting over titles, our focus should be to make it easier to build anywhere. Better internet, lower compliance, and decentralised access to capital. We should stop forcing startups to relocate for funding.

India’s tech future isn’t in one city-it’s in all of them. Let’s stop playing real estate games and start building the future. India is the perfect storm of talent, cost, market size, and ambition. Build here, and you’re not just solving for India; you’re solving for humanity.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-03-04 06:11:30', 'relative': '9 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1741065090683}
text:
There are over 500+ brands competing in India's healthy food market across quick commerce, online marketplaces & offline. Having engaged with over 80+ brands and investing in 10, there are some patterns & hard truths about scaling in this crowded space. This is a breakdown on marketing and distribution in healthy foods for founders & marketers.

First, here’s what you need to know about Indian consumers.

- Indians buy food based on trust, not just marketing – If a celebrity promotes it but their neighbour or friend doesn’t recommend it, they won’t buy it. Word of mouth is king.

- There is low willingness to pay premium, but high spend on indulgence. People will hesitate on a ₹200 protein bar but will happily buy a ₹500 artisanal mithai box. You need to frame health as indulgence, not sacrifice.

-They snack, they don’t diet. Instead of selling "healthy diets", sell better snacking alternatives. That’s why makhanas, chikkis, and seed mixes work.

- Unlike the west, 70% of discretionary food spend happens during festivals. Brands that nails Diwali, Rakhi, Ramzan and weddings will win.

-Instead of mimicking the US health food market, make Indian-first products. Local trumps global. India is not one country, it’s 20 mini-countries. What works in North won’t work in South. Regional customization is key.

- Indians love flavor and indulgence. If your product doesn’t taste good first, it won’t sell. Aim to be a weekly purchase, not a one-time trend.

Marketing Don'ts 

- Don't sell fear, guilt or magic. Most health marketers are doing exactly this. Fear of missing out on fitness. Guilt of not eating right. Magic solutions promising six-pack abs in six weeks,  “clinically tested” shortcuts . Health marketing shouldn’t be a psychological warfare. 

-Don't hijack medical language. Just because you put "backed by science" or "doctor-approved" in your ad ,doesn’t make it true. Most people don’t know what a randomized controlled trial is, but that doesn’t mean you should exploit their ignorance. Don’t throw a lab coat on a model, add "Doctor recommended," and hope no one asks which doctor.

-Don't create fake urgency – "Only 3 packs left of our exclusive superfood". Healthy eating isn’t a flash sale; trust and quality build long-term customers, not gimmicks.

Marketing Do’s

- The best health brands don’t sell a product, they sell a perspective. Tell the truth, but make it interesting.
If your product actually works, people will come back. No need to bait them with fake promises. Play the long game.

-The best marketing in health is knowledge. Teach people something useful, and they’ll trust you. Educate, don’t manipulate.

- Be honest, be helpful, and respect your customer’s intelligence. Anything else is just snake oil in new packaging. If your health product needs tricks to sell, it’s probably not worth buying. 

More notes on distribution and growth shared in the comments section. Hope this is useful to founders , marketers and their brands.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-02-27 06:06:47', 'relative': '9 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1740632807970}
text:
If you’re an entrepreneur building for healthcare in India, don’t replicate U.S. or China models. It won’t work. I don’t know why many folks continue chasing templates that don’t fit India’s healthcare landscape. This is a breakdown for you.

To set context, there are three forces that shape Indian Healthcare:
#1 Out-of-pocket expenditure: 54% of healthcare spending comes directly from patients (vs. 10% in the U.S., 35% in China).
#2 70% of outpatient care is in private hospitals, while 60% of hospital beds are in government facilities. 80% of care is delivered by single-doctor clinics. 
#3 Urban India has 3.9 doctors per 1,000 people, rural India just 0.7. That’s the doctor density disparity.

Lets understand the U.S. market
The U.S. healthcare system runs on high-margin insurance networks, specialist-driven monopolies, and tech-heavy solutions like AI diagnostics and boutique hospitals. Their system is expensive, fragmented, and complex. 

Why this will not work in in India-
#1 54% of Americans (180M people) get health coverage through their jobs. In India, only 6% do.
#2 U.S. hospitals mark up services 10x because insurers pay. In India, patients haggle upfront—no room for inflated billing.
#3 U.S. hospitals profit from complex billing ($500 MRI scans). India’s best healthcare models profit from volume—Aravind Eye Care performs cataract surgeries at 1/1000th the U.S. cost. Incentives misaligned for India.
#4 70% of Indians distrust private insurers (NSSO 2021). Insurance covers just 30% of healthcare costs (vs. 91% in the U.S.). Premium models here exclude 800M+ Indians earning <$5/day.

Now lets understand the China market
China runs a hybrid system with state control, digital super-apps, and vertically integrated hospitals. AI-powered diagnostics, government-backed telemedicine, and centralized data help scale. 

But India’s reality differs: Why this will not work in India-
#1 China has 3 national insurers; India has 50+ state schemes and 25+ private insurers. Interoperability is a pipe dream.
#2 China’s 1.4B health records are centralized. India’s digital health ID (Ayushman Bharat) has 500M registrations, but less than 5% have usable data. 
#3 China mandates compliance overnight. India’s 28 states have 28 regulatory frameworks. Unlike China, Indians distrust centralized control.
#4 China’s 1.4B people speak Mandarin. India’s 1.4B speak 22+ official languages. A Hindi-first telemedicine app fails in Tamil Nadu.

If you really want to build a large healthcare company in India build from first principles- solve affordability & distribution. What can you do? 
More notes shared in the comments section

posted_at: {'date': '2025-02-25 06:30:06', 'relative': '9 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1740461406130}
text:
India just beat Pakistan in cricket, and the entire country lit up in celebration. Celebrities and leaders flooded social media with praise, traditional media turned it into a spectacle and LinkedIn is overflowing with leadership lessons. The cricket team deserves every bit of this recognition.

But so do the many other athletes who have made India proud with their achievements, yet no one is talking about them.

-Gulveer Singh just became the first Indian to run a 5000m race in under 13 minutes, setting a new national record. A superhuman feat—yet, our timelines remain silent.
-Pankaj Advani won his 14th Asian gold in snooker and is setting records like a hobby. Barely a mention.
-Saurav Ghosal came out of retirement and won an international squash title in Sydney. No one noticed.
-India’s U-21 men’s archery team shattered a world record at the ongoing Asia Cup. Few even realize that India is a powerhouse in this sport.

And all of this happened in just the past week.

We are what we celebrate. If we only cheer for cricket, we will only be a cricketing nation. If we only celebrate one sport, we shouldn’t expect that India will dominate the Olympics. If we want to be a sporting country, we need to start valuing sports beyond cricket. We can’t develop world-class sports talent when our entire system is designed to ignore them.

Attention in India is a monopoly and cricket owns it. And like any monopoly, it strangles competition. A billion people are celebrating one sport while world-class athletes in other sports struggle for recognition. If kids never see champions outside cricket, they never dream beyond cricket. If brands don’t see ROI, they won’t invest. If the media doesn’t cover it, the public won’t care.

This isn’t just about fairness but survival. Sport is more than entertainment. It is culture, identity, and power.

And the power is also in hands of most of us. So next time an Indian athlete wins anything, anywhere, let’s also celebrate them. Post about them. Talk about them. If a billion of us can scream for a six, we can clap for a world and national record.

A sporting nation isn’t built on one game. It’s built on celebrating all champions. Change starts with attention. Where you look is what grows.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-02-22 06:12:18', 'relative': '9 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1740201138058}
text:
Gopi is right. The reality is brutal—less than 1% of aspiring athletes make it big, and even those who do are left with little security once their careers are over. Sports, like startups, have a power law distribution—10% of players make 90% of the money. Everyone else is a statistic.

We love to read and watch the underdog story—the kid from nowhere who makes it to the top. But that’s survivorship bias. For every one success, there are tens of thousands who trained just as hard but got nothing. The real question is: why does sports have to be a gamble?

 If you’re not in the top 1%, you don’t get sponsorships, you don’t have financial security, and once your career ends—usually in your late 20’s or early 30s—you’re left scrambling for what’s next.

In developed nations, sports is a structured industry. There are leagues, second-tier careers, college scholarships, and post-career pathways. 

If you don’t become an Olympic champion, you can still earn a living as a coach, analyst, trainer, or minor league player. The system doesn’t discard you the moment you’re not in the top 1%.

The problem isn’t that sports is hard—it’s that failure is absolute. An engineer who fails at a startup can get a job. A failed athlete? They often have nothing. That’s why in most countries without strong sports ecosystems, success in sports correlates with wealth. You can’t afford to be an athlete unless you can afford to lose.

Right now, telling a poor kid to pursue sports is like telling them to buy lottery tickets as an investment strategy. Until we change that, Gopi’s words will remain true. And that’s a failure—not of the athletes, but of the system.

A great sports system doesn’t just create champions—it creates a nation of resilient, disciplined, and competitive people. And that’s the foundation of real development.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-02-20 06:03:28', 'relative': '9 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1740027808267}
text:
Yesterday, I met a 26yo year old boy making YouTube videos to educate young girls about menstrual health. No sponsors, no brand deals, no fancy equipment—just knowledge, freely shared. His motivation was the struggles his sister faced growing up.

This is the side of content creation people rarely see in India. Because it doesn’t go viral. It doesn’t spark outrage or fuel controversy. 

In the past few days, there’s been a lot of noise about content creators-their influence, their controversies. A few loud voices stir outrage, and suddenly, the entire ecosystem of creators is under fire. The attention economy is ruthless- outrage is a currency and algorithms reward volume, not knowledge.

But the internet remains the last true frontier of leverage. With just a phone and an idea, a single person can achieve what once took institutions, gatekeepers, and millions in capital. It’s a superpower and like all superpowers, it’s all about how we use it.

Yes, there’s noise and chaos. But beneath it, there are builders, educators, and creators using this leverage to make the world a little better.

The internet doesn’t care what we consume or create. But in the long run, we become what we feed our mind. The question isn’t whether content creation is good or bad. 

The question is: what are we using it for. If you want better content, make it. The leverage is in our hands. Don’t let the algorithm decide your future.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-02-18 06:05:35', 'relative': '9 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1739855135019}
text:
Building a business in preventive health is hard. No one tells you this upfront. I learned it the hard way, first as a founder, now as an investor.

You’ve chosen the harder game. Not because prevention doesn’t work, but because people don’t pay for it. Most wake up thinking about chai, parathas , deadlines, and school fees. Not long-term health. People today want instant gratification—sugar today, gym tomorrow.

Curative health makes money because illness is urgent. No one postpones a bypass surgery or negotiates an ICU bill. But prevention? Everyone hunts for gym discounts, coupon codes for healthy food and thinks twice before paying for a fitness program.

Hospitals & pharma companies thrive because they sell relief from suffering. And suffering is a guaranteed market—prevention is not.

That’s why venture money chases curative health—it scales fast with clear unit economics, solving problems people can’t ignore. Asking someone to eat better, sleep more, and exercise for a payoff 5–10 years later is like selling an FD over a lottery ticket. So accept this reality and build accordingly.

Yet, prevention is the hardest problem and the biggest untaped opportunity.
#1 Healthcare in India will shift to prevention-not because people suddenly care, but because not caring is becoming too expensive. 

#2 Your market isn’t TAM, it’s WTM (willing-to-pay market). Everyone should care about health, but few will pay for it.To go mass-market, make it cheaper than chai and as seamless as WhatsApp.

#3 If you’re selling prevention, reposition it. People don’t buy prevention. They buy status, performance, and convenience. Make it aspirational & competitive.

#4 Trust in health isn’t built overnight. People won’t change their habits because you raised venture money. You’re in the business of delayed gratification. That means slow &sustainable growth.

#5 If your product doesn’t make people healthier or keep them engaged long-term, the number of app downloads doesn't matter. Focus on retention, real outcomes and revenue—not GMV, DAUs or metrics to make a pitch deck look good. 

If you can do this, you won’t just build a business—you’ll change how India thinks about health. And that’s worth building for.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-02-16 06:46:35', 'relative': '9 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1739684795894}
text:
Most Indian employers overcomplicate employee wellness. It’s not about step challenges, yoga, Zumba sessions, or Friday parties.

64% of employees in India report high workplace stress and burnout.
Stress isn’t about long hours—it’s the rigid work culture. Being stuck in a 9-to-6 cycle, drowning in meetings, commuting for hours, and worrying about not being there for family. That’s the real health hazard.
No amount of meditation sessions will fix that.

Let people work async. Let them go for a run in the afternoon. Let them sleep in when their body needs it. Let them care for their kids or aging parents—without guilt or permission.

The healthiest employees aren’t in wellness programs—they’re designing their own lives. The rest is noise.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-02-11 06:17:20', 'relative': '9 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1739251040244}
text:
We've invested in 35+ health companies in India and these are some observations on what works (and doesn't). If you're a founder building in health and planning to raise funds, these notes are for you.

1) Trust is the only moat in preventive health. In healthcare, people don’t buy products. They buy trust. Preventive health is not an impulse purchase. Unlike sick-care, preventive health requires behavior change, which Indians resist unless they deeply trust the source.
So, before you raise money, ask yourself:
-Do people trust you enough to pay upfront, or do you need constant marketing?
-Is there real evidence that your intervention works—or is it just another diet plan, gadget, or wellness promise?
If you don’t have a strong, organic trust loop, raising VC money won’t help. Money can buy ads, but it can’t buy credibility.

2) Distribution is your Intellectual Property. In preventive health, distribution is the product. Without it, you’re just another marketing agency. India is filled with "next-gen" fitness apps, ayurveda solutions, and longevity programs—most fail because they don’t solve the hardest problem: distribution.
You should only raise money when:
-You have a low-CAC, high-retention acquisition channel—word of mouth, organic virality, or a B2B partner who does the heavy lifting. 
-You don’t rely on Google/Facebook ads to acquire users. 
Most preventive health startups mistake marketing for product. 

3) Your real product is the outcome. Preventive health isn’t about engagement, it’s about results. Indians don’t pay for health advice—they pay for outcomes. If your model is content-based or habit-driven but lacks measurable outcomes, you will struggle to justify raising any money. 
Before you raise money, prove:
-Measurable outcomes: What % of users improved their health? 
- Behavior stickiness: How many users are still with you after 6 months? Is this a short-term motivation spike or a lasting habit?
-Revenue beyond one-time purchases: Subscription, long-term engagement, or ecosystem lock-in.
The worst mistake you can make is optimising for likes, shares, time spent,  instead of real-world health results.

4) You should only raise money when you’ve proven at least one of these:
Distribution: You’ve hacked a scalable way to acquire patients/customers without burning money on ads.
Clinical Efficacy: Your product has regulatory approval, proven clinical outcomes, or strong signals of delivering outcomes. 
Network Effects: Your product becomes more valuable as more people use it.

5) In India, you’re not fighting incumbents. You’re fighting inertia. Unlike in the U.S., where insurers or employers drive adoption, in India: 
-Hospitals are conservative and slow-moving. Selling to them takes years.
-Doctors are overworked. Adoption needs to be frictionless.
-Consumers pay out of pocket. If you need to educate them, your CAC will kill you.

Hope these notes are useful. Good luck to all building in Health in India.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-02-06 06:47:10', 'relative': '9 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1738820830804}
text:
We have two choice to fix air pollution issue. Either we argue, debate, and wait for someone else to fix it. Some government intervention or corporate responsibility. That’s a passive way to live.

Or start having conversations on how each of us can contribute our part right away. 33,000 people die in India, annually from to air pollution in just 10 Indian cities.

#1 Start at home and get an AQI monitor Measure your air and know what you and your kids are breathing. Use air purifiers. Create a clean space for sleeping and breathing. Insist your workplace and kids school to install a monitor and ask them publish the AQI regularly. 

#2 Stay fit. Your lungs, heart, and immune system are your best defense. Regular exercise, clean eating, and strong respiratory health will make you more resilient to pollution’s effects. A weak body suffers more.

#3 If every school, apartment complex, and office block planted more trees, we wouldn’t just improve air quality, we’d create cooler, cleaner neighborhoods. Plant trees not because it’s trendy. Because it’s basic math. More green, cleaner air.

#4 If construction is happening near your home, insist on dust control measures—sprinkling water, covering debris, and using dust barriers. Pollution from construction is a silent killer, but it’s preventable.

#5 Avoid unnecessary travel in high pollution zones. Protect your lungs like you would protect your wealth. Mask wisely. If the air is bad, wear a proper N95 when outdoors. Not for fear, but for protection.

No one is coming to save you. The world is run by inertia. The system will take decades to correct itself. Your children & parents don’t have decades.

The air we breathe is the first gift of life, and the last we’ll surrender.

The US and China didn’t lead in AI because of influencer summits. They did it through university labs, open-source contributions, and startup founders building from first principles. We need to build an ecosystem to listen and learn from builders. 

Technology isn’t a spectator sport. If India wants to lead, we must put real builders at the center of the conversation.

text:
Most people assume every business needs funding but the truth is, not every business should take it. Not every entrepreneur dreams of an exit. Some dream of a journey. And that’s perfectly ok. You are not alone.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-01-15 06:17:46', 'relative': '10 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1736918266161}
text:
We meet atleast 20 companies every month building solutions for longevity. Billions of dollars are being spent. Met Bryan Jhonson who spends $2million every year on his own longevity. Sharing some observations from an investor and an health enthusiast perspective for India. 

#1 Everyone loves the idea of a pill or device that adds 50 years to life. But longevity is 80% lifestyle and 20% intervention. Companies chasing the 20% often overpromise and underdeliver. Don’t exploit people’s fear of death or disease to sell products & supplements leading to skepticism and distrust.

#2 Blood tests and wearables measure everything now—glucose, cortisol, telomeres. But data without actionable insights is just noise. A longer life needs meaningful action, not just analytics. Don’t over emphasise on biomarkers without a feedback loop to fix it. Build tools that have clear clinical and user adoption pathways.

#3 Investors want quick ROI, but longevity isn’t a sprint, it’s a marathon. Companies chasing valuations as a metric often neglect the slow, foundational research required. Your core product will accelerate your valuation if you deliver outcome. Don’t promise timelines that ignore the inherent long cycles of research, trials, and regulatory approvals.

#4 The key isn’t to stop aging but to improve healthspan—living well until the end. Companies prioritizing quality over quantity of life are the real winners. Build systems on aging as a process to address muscle loss or inflammation rather than waiting for chronic disease onset.

#5 You can’t engineer longevity if people won’t adopt the solutions. Companies that understand habit formation and human psychology will create an IP. The future of longevity isn’t in more tech but in accessible, scalable solutions—better sleep, balanced nutrition, and community support. These “boring” fixes will outlast flashy innovations.

#6 Women experience aging differently but are often overlooked in longevity-focused research. Focus on women’s health. Also longevity studies need to be diverse. We can’t be using datasets primarily from high-income countries and build solutions for people in low and middle-income populations.

#7 Don’t associate longevity with celebrity faces to generate PR. This will lack substance and meaningful validation.

Remember, people don’t just want to live longer. They want to live better. Focus on delivering that as your metric. 

If you’re building something meaningful in this space, happy to exchange notes.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-01-12 06:25:50', 'relative': '10 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1736659550010}
text:
If you are keen to solve for problems that has the greatest impact on humanity, it is opportunities in health and climate. And now is the time to start solving. 

1) Over 2 billion people worldwide lack access to safe drinking water- WHO.

2) At least half the world’s population does not have full access to essential health services- World Bank

3) Roughly 828 million people go to bed hungry every night- UN World Food Programme

4) Approx 244 million children globally are out of school- UNESCO

5) Nearly 9 million deaths annually are linked to pollution, particularly air pollution – Lancet Commission on Pollution and Health.

6) Over 600 million people, or 1 in 10, fall ill each year after eating contaminated food – WHO.

7) One-third of all food produced globally, approximately 1.3 billion tons, is wasted each year, while millions go hungry – FAO.

8) Climate change could push 100 million people into extreme poverty by 2030 – World Bank.

9) Around 931 million tons of CO2 emissions annually come from food waste, contributing significantly to global warming – UNEP.

10) 2.4 billion people globally live without proper sanitation-  WHO

The world’s biggest problems are humanity’s greatest opportunities. This is the time to build and solve something meaningful and start where the pain is greatest and the leverage is highest.

At Rainmatter by Zerodha , we want to be on the side of entrepreneurs solving for these issues.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-01-09 06:31:55', 'relative': '10 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1736400715423}
text:
Indians want to eat healthy and companies want to make healthier alternatives. But both customers and brands are often confused.  Health food is a $30B market in India and we meet atleast 20 companies every week. My last post on Indians eating protein got a lot of attention. So here is a playbook for brands, entrepreneurs & startups making food as nutrition to consider.

#1- Sell simplicity, not superiority. Protein is not a luxury, it’s a necessity. Stop marketing it like it’s only for bodybuilders or fitness fanatics. The simpler your message, the broader your audience.

#2- Educate, don’t exploit- Most Indians don’t know how much protein , carb or fibre they need, let alone where to get it. Be the brand that empowers with knowledge, not fear. Create tools, guides, or calculators that simplify nutrient requirements for different age groups, lifestyles, and budgets. Education creates trust, and trust builds loyalty.

#3- Respect local wisdom- Stop chasing western trends and start celebrating Indian staples. Align your messaging with cultural relevance—it resonates deeper than imported fads.

#4- Focus on affordability and accessibility- If your product costs more than an average meal, you’re solving a problem for the few, not the many. Create products that cater to the masses, especially rural and low-income communities. Affordability isn’t just ethical—it’s scalable.

#5-Champion the underserved - Protein or carbs isn’t just for athletes or gym-goers. It’s crucial for children, pregnant women, and the elderly and they often are left out of the conversation. Tailor your products and campaigns to serve them, and you’ll stand out as a brand with purpose, not just profits.

#6- Break the high-protein Halo - A “high-protein” claim shouldn’t be your only story. Focus on the overall quality of your product—minimal additives, real ingredients, and transparent labeling. If your protein bar has more sugar than a laddoo, you’re part of the problem, not the solution.

#7- Decommoditize the narrative - Don’t just sell protein or fibre—sell the idea of a healthier India. Be the brand that shifts the conversation from “how much protein you eat” to “how balanced your diet is.” Make protein part of the bigger picture, not the entire story.

#8-Make nutrient consumption a Public Good- Don’t just sell specific nutrient products; create ecosystems that make nutrient accessible and affordable for everyone. Collaborate with local governments to integrate protein-rich foods into public programs like midday meals and ration systems. You’ll build long-term demand while addressing a systemic health challenge."

More notes continued in the comment section below.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-01-06 05:50:14', 'relative': '10 months ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1736139014834}
text:
Indians are not eating enough protein. This narrative has been making rounds for the past few years amplified by fitness influencers, nutritionists and brands. At Rainmatter by Zerodha, we’ve invested in ten companies making different form factors of protein consumption with the hope that we need a balanced ecosystem for nutrition. 

My general view is that the the protein story in India is becoming less of a nutrient and more of an identity. It’s what you consume to signal you’re part of the “aware” and “fit” crowd. This is what i've been observing. 

#1- In urban India, protein powders and supplements have become the new status symbol. You’re not really working out unless you’re Instagramming your shaker bottle. It’s less about nutrition and more about validation.

#2- Protein enthusiasts often villainize carbs and demonise other macro nutrients as if they’re the root of all health problems. India thrives on a carbohydrate-rich culture—rotis, rice, dosas—but demonizing carbs overlooks balance. You need energy to sprint, not just to squat.

#3- The idea that protein comes only from a powder tub priced like a luxury item is flawed. Whole food are getting sidelined in favor of trendy solutions.

#4- India might be the only country that has the highest cultural protein diversity. Traditional diets are already protein rich- lentils, curd, paneer, fish or chicken are ingrained in our cuisine. 

#5 -Urban India is obsessed over consuming protein within 30 minutes of a workout, treating the post-gym meal as sacred. I think it’s a “Protein Timing” Myth. Your body isn’t checking the clock. it’s about overall daily intake.

#6- The conversation around protein in India is hyper-focused on gym-goers and athletes. Meanwhile, the elderly—who desperately need more protein to preserve muscle mass and bone health are left out of the discussion entirely.

Look, protein is a tool, not a trophy. It’s one piece of a larger puzzle—like building a house with bricks but ignoring the foundation. Somewhere along the way, we lost the nuance and turned nutrition into a black-and-white debate.

Eat more protein, sure. But do it with purpose, not propaganda. Because at the end of the day, nutrition isn’t about being part of a trend. It’s about being part of a better life.

If you're entrepreneur building solutions in this space or an enthusiast of this category, i've some thoughts on what should be and can be done to build an ecosystem that benefits all. Will share some notes tomorrow.

posted_at: {'date': '2025-01-03 05:26:53', 'relative': '11 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1735878413172}
text:
Hi Albinder, this is a much needed and important service. Cheering for you and team to bring impact. We met a bunch of companies in emergency care category for supporting them via Rainmatter. 

Sharing notes from what we observed. Hoping it’s useful to your team working on this project. 

First, ambulance services in India aren’t a technology problem or even a logistics problem. They’re a coordination and trust problem. The best service won’t be the one that arrives the fastest but the one that creates a system people trust to save them when it matters.

1) Most companies we met obsess over response times, aiming for unrealistic goals like “X” minute arrivals. speed is critical but treatment initiation time and survival rates are more important metric. Faster doesn’t always mean better outcomes; preparedness matters more.

2) There’s a race to equip ambulances with cutting-edge tech, assuming it’s a game-changer. But a well-trained paramedic with basic tools can often save more lives than an undertrained individual with a ventilator they barely know how to use. Unfortunately, in India skill training is still an underrated aspect of operating. 

3) The belief that more ambulances solve the problem is misguided. In more metro cities, poor traffic management and a lack of awareness about yielding to ambulances neutralize fleet size advantages. But you guys have the brand  authority to create awareness and educate people on basic road etiquette’s . Smaller companies can’t do what you can. 

4) Pre arrival communication. Many lives can be saved by guiding the bystanders or family members on basic first aid before the ambulance arrives. Simple steps like positioning a patient correctly can buy precious time.

Operating an ambulance service in India is about optimizing for chaos—a system where traffic, infrastructure, and trust deficits compete with time-sensitive medical needs. Success lies not in being faster, shinier, or cheaper but in being smarter, simpler, and more human.

Good luck to you and team to make real impact with this service. Really want this service to succeed. 

And if the team wants to collaborate with the operators /founders who are already solving for this, can connect to the startups we have met.

text:
If you are planning to start the new year with a resolution to get healthy & fit, don’t do that. I was doing that mistake for most part of my life.

Buying a subscription to apps won’t make you calm. Buying the new offer to a gym membership won’t make you fit. 

Time, effort and commitment is what you pay. If you can’t do it tomorrow, you won’t do it ever. You are only fooling yourself. 

The progress in your fitness is the gap between your desire and commitment. 

Your only resolution in life should be to be in your family’s life as long as you can. And staying healthy now is the only way to get that. 

You are the greatest project you’ll ever work on.

text:
India is the perfect storm of talent, cost, market size, and ambition. Build here, and you’re not just solving for India; you’re solving for humanity.

Depending on how you look, there is an opportunity in every problem. 
India is a giant laboratory for human behaviour.
In India, you’re forced to innovate with limited resources.
India is full of paradoxes—rich and poor, traditional and modern, local and global. 
India operates at high entropy—systems are broken, markets are fragmented, and solutions are often patchwork. But entropy means energy, and energy means potential.

-India is projected to become the third-largest economy by 2030.

-Second-largest internet user base globally.
65% of the population is under 35 years old, making it one of the youngest workforces globally.

India is chaos distilled into opportunity. Decode it, and you unlock infinite leverage. India is the best place in the world to build right now.

If you're building something for India , happy to talk and find ways to cheer you.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-12-25 06:20:51', 'relative': '11 months ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1735104051472}
text:
We reviewed 800+ health startups in India this year. Met 200+ founders in person. These are entrepreneurs building across health tech, fitness, nutrition, software for doctors, diagnostics, healthy food, longevity, sports, elder care, women health, lifestyle management & more. 

This is a long post on everything we've seen and observed in 2024 at Rainmatter by Zerodha. If you're an entrepreneur, investor of health enthusiast, this is for you. 

1) There is a telemedicine fatigue- The post-pandemic boom in telemedicine has plateaued. While accessibility improved, sustainable consumer engagement still remains a challenge due to weak doctor-patient relationship and lack of differentiation. Patients want emotional and personalised engagement. Most companies are overusing AI in the disguise of scale. Opportunity is to solve for depth (chronic disease management) rather than breadth (generic consultation marketplaces).

2) Overload of premium fitness and wellness Apps- Apps targeting high-income urban users are oversaturated. Most startups overestimate the willingness of users to pay for digital fitness content. Opportunity is to focus on communities, hybrid models (offline + online), or affordable mass-market solutions. India is still not ready for Peloton content. We breathe YouTube.

3) Selling SaaS tools to Doctors- Doctors in India are notoriously price-sensitive. Most SaaS products fail due to limited willingness to adopt technology and low ROI visibility. Maybe companies should emphasise on simplicity and immediate value delivery. Job of a Doctor is to deliver treatment to patients and not learn how to use software. Need to humanise software in primary and secondary health care

4) Longevity buzz- Longevity startups sound exciting but cater to a niche. Everyone loves the idea of a pill or device that adds 50 years to life. But longevity is 80% lifestyle and 20% intervention. Startups chasing the 20% often overpromise and underdeliver. Without a strong clinical base or mass appeal, they will remain limited to aspirational urban elites. Opportunity is in integrating into broader wellness solutions rather than standalone ventures

5) Healthy food & nutrition- Overcrowding of “healthy snacks” and “superfoods” where differentiation is low and margins are squeezed by Quick commerce and logistics. Maybe companies should move beyond buzzwords like “organic” or “keto” and solve for authentic, local, and culturally aligned nutrition. India is a country of a million palates

6) Chronic disease management- Diabetes, hypertension, Weight loss and mental health requires long-term engagement and behaviour modification. While the space is competitive, there is room for solutions that prioritise patient journeys and retention over time. Driving outcome has to be the focus. Everything else is a vanity feature that doesn’t earn trust. Paid marketing will get expensive customers who won’t stick around

Sharing the remaining notes in the comments section. Read below

text:
Yesterday a 8yo was arguing with his dad in the elevator to get him a Christmas tree in 10 mins. The dad explained it wasn’t possible and offered to take him to the nearest shop. The boy pointed to the banner ad on the wall that said "Ab dus min mein Santa Claus ghar pe". We've ruined our future generation with a condition of instant satisfaction and robbed them from the joy of earning things over time. 

Teaching a child to find joy in patience and not race for instant gratification will be the most impactful lesson in education for future generation. A child who appreciates the journey will be richer than one fixated on quick rewards.

Ignoring some people for your mental health is not a weakness. It is your superpower.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-11-23 06:33:02', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1732339982273}
text:
If you’re an entrepreneur just starting out, I want you to know this- the most important thing you’ll need to drive your entrepreneurial journey isn’t money. It’s that one person who believes in you. That person could be a family member, a friend, or even a stranger.

For me, that person was Nithin Kamath. He had no reason to believe in me. I was a nobody in the startup world—no background in high-tech companies, no premier academic credentials. I knew literally no one in the startup ecosystem who could vouch for me. But he took a bet on me. One cold email in 2019 led to a meaningful relationship that has shaped my journey.

And he didn’t just bet on me once—he did it twice. First, as an investor, and later with the opportunity to build Rainmatter Health.

So, don’t let rejection from investors define your passion or commitment. Just wait for that one person to show up. They will.

text:
Entrepreneurs- if you’re building products to help people stay healthy this meetup is for you. Rainmatter is a venture fund supporting companies making products that helps Indians to stay healthy, mentally and physically.

This is the first time we’re doing a meetup in Bangalore. The last two was in Delhi and Mumbai and it was was super fun.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-11-02 06:17:02', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1730524622002}
text:
Priceless words by Jeff Bezos. 
The difference between gifts and choices. Cleverness is a gift; kindness is a choice. Gifts are easy—they’re given after all. Choices can be hard. In the end, we are our choices.

This is something that’s super important for young people to understand, and for parents to preach to young people. It’s really easy for a talented young person to take pride in their gifts: ‘I’m really athletic,’ or ‘I’m really smart,’ or ‘I’m really good at math.’ That’s fine. You should celebrate your gifts. You should be happy. But you can’t be proud of them. What you can be proud of is your choices.”

Did you work hard? That’s a choice.
Did you study hard? That’s a choice.
Did you practice? That’s a choice.

The people who excel combine gifts and hard work, and the hard work part is a choice.

we are our choices.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-10-16 07:31:42', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1729056702147}
text:
There are some untold realities of healthcare industry that you will only understand through your own experiences. Learning will come at the cost of suffering. But you should know this- 

- The more complex the treatment, the more you should question its necessity.
- People will sell magic diets because the truth is too boring: eat less, move more.
-Health trends are made to be sold, not to work.
-People will often dress common sense as breakthrough science.
-The more a product claims to fix all your problems, the more likely it’s fixing none.
-In fitness, ‘results in 30 days’ is just code for ‘we will be back to sell you more.
-Doctors aren’t always wrong, but they rarely say ‘I don’t know.’
-The healthiest advice costs nothing, but people pay for complexity to avoid discomfort.
	
Remember, healthcare thrives on your ignorance. The real risk in healthcare is trusting someone who profits when you don’t understand.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-10-09 07:10:15', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1728450615356}
text:
Have met over 600+ healthcare startups this year at Rainmatter. These are my general observations of the sector in 2024 so far. An investor & health enthusiast perspective. 

Remember, these are observations and not opinions.  If you’re a builder, I'm always keen to exchange notes.

1) Health tech needs maturing – The novelty phase of tech meets health is over and the focus should be on driving outcomes to the user.

2) Preventive health is gaining traction – More startups are focused on preventive solutions.

3) Nutrition personalisation is heating up – Companies are going beyond generic consulting and leveraging DNA, microbiome, or other personal data for nutrition recommendations.

4) UPI for health not yet in India- ABDM use cases haven't seen much adoption.

5) Wearables are no longer the star – Smartwatches and rings are still strong but are considered table stakes. Consumers want something that tells “why” and not limited to “what”.

6) Corporate wellness is an overrated market – With rising mental health issues, stress, and burnout in the workforce, B2B wellness solutions ideally should show promise. But there isn’t adoption from corporates.

7) The “biohacking” trend is niche but growing –longevity startups are speculative but hot.  Increasing interest in biohacking protocols (sleep optimization, anti ageing etc.). But the market is niche and often hard to validate scientifically unless clinical protocols are done.

8) Consumer trust in health supplements is dwindling – The supplement industry lacks regulation and transparency and this has eroded trust amongst consumers. Brands are focusing on science-backed products.

9) AI in healthcare – Many are bullish on AI’s potential to revolutionise diagnostics, patient care, and drug discovery, but deployment in clinical settings is slow and capital-intensive.

10) Mental health is booming – Digital mental health startups, especially those offering therapy, coaching, or CBT solutions are seeing adoptions but differentiation is becoming a challenge in a crowded market.

11) Community-driven fitness – Social, community-oriented fitness solutions still have potential if done right especially those blending real-world interactions with digital offerings.

12) CAC is a challenge for D2C health brands – Brands are facing rising customer acquisition costs often with no sustainable GTM.

13) Hybrid health businesses are scaling better – Companies combining digital and physical services have better scope of scaling fast.

14) Telehealth plateaued – The initial excitement around telehealth has subsided for both consumers and investors.

15) Health marketplaces have no moat – Platforms connecting consumers with healthcare providers or wellness services are overrated with no clear moat to grow.

There are more thoughts on this. Because of the word limit on Linkedin , can't post the remaining here. Read the whole list on https://lnkd.in/g-CTY4zC

posted_at: {'date': '2024-09-14 06:56:11', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1726289771013}
text:
I think the definition of being healthy and looking fit is a modern-day confusion caused by social media. Don’t know why people fail to understand that being fit is not equal to being healthy. 

Most people believe being healthy and being fit are one and the same. It’s not. They are not synonymous and are distinct states of physical well-being. 

Being fit means your ability to perform physical activities like endurance, stamina, strength, & speed. These are a set of attributes that people have or train to develop to perform a physical activity. 

Being healthy is a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being. Your physiological and internal biological systems should be working in harmony. 

We often look at athletes or movie stars as fit and healthy. But most times they are not. Going to a gym or doing a run doesn’t get you a heart attack or stroke. Overdoing it might. So do everything in the right proportion. 

Being fit can contribute to overall health and yet it's possible for someone to be physically fit but still experience health issues due to poor nutrition, stress, lack of sleep, or underlying medical conditions. 

We all live a hectic life and are exposed to stress and distractions all the time. It’s more important for people who prioritize fitness to balance it with healthy living. Stress + rest = growth. 

1- Get your blood tests done at regular intervals.
2- Consult your physician. Not your WhatsApp friends.
3- Seek help from a qualified nutritionist and trainer. Not Instagram or YouTube influencers.
4- Spend less time doing commentary on Whatsapp groups and more with your family and friends.  

The progress in your fitness or health is the gap between your desire and commitment. Don’t over burden it with confusion.

text:
India has 5 hospital beds & 8.6 doctors for every 10,000 people today. That’s among the lowest in the world by WHO standards.


We’ve approx 1.3 million registered doctors & 70 thousand hospitals. Still India is largely an underserved country for healthcare coverage. 

If you are a consumer worried about the uneven healthcare access in India. 
Your only priority should be to stay healthy and fit. Both mentally and physically. Eat right, exercise & sleep well. 

If you are an entrepreneur or aspiring to solve for healthcare, your opportunity is to build preventive health solutions that doesn’t add load to doctors or hospitals. They are already overworked. Solutions that drive outcomes and progress in health is the need. Help Indians to save on their medical expenses.

At Rainmatter by Zerodha we’ve now partnered with over 25 startups and entrepreneurs helping to keep Indians stay healthy & fit. We will continue to support more. If you’re solving and driving outcomes for health, we will be on your side.

text:
I don’t understand why there is so much enthusiasm amongst young folks to become a VC. We need more young builders in the country. I’m confused on what to share when people ask me for guidance to make a career in venture world.

Becoming an investor and continuing to be a useful investor are two different skills.

You can scout founders and read pitch decks as a young VC. But to become a useful investor you need empathy, patience and ask the right questions. This skill is a muscle that is only developed if you have built something in the past.

I’ve been an entrepreneur for most part of my life. Did many mistakes while figuring how to build a business. 

Now, I’m on the other side cheering entrepreneurs learning from their mistakes and still figuring how to do business :)

So, go and build things and be useful. It’s a moat that one sould have in their career.

This is Paris Jasmin. One of my inspirations who proves you can do sports even with a full time job. She is a Ph.D. in cancer stem cell and works as a clinical lecturer on chronic liver diseases. 

She became the first women ever to complete the 100mile plus Barkley marathon. It's one of the most difficult and cruel ultra-marathon race in the world. 160 km race, 5 laps of 32 km each inside a forest. No navigation & no support. Before this year, only 17 men no women had ever completed the race which takes in 63,000 feet of elevation – more than twice the height of Mount Everest. Paris- you are amazing!

posted_at: {'date': '2024-08-19 06:34:09', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1724042049138}
text:
Last week i completed 18 months being on other the side of entrepreneurship. Being a partner and cheerleader to entrepreneurs. I was not engineered for this role and continue to feel stretched between a builder and an investor. 

Every 6months, i share my learnings from this role to my team at Rainmatter by Zerodha. This is what i shared with them last week. 

1. The most effective way to critique something is by creating an improved version. It’s easier for investors to pass judgments on founders but much harder to do what they do. Critiques are overrated. Being useful is underrated.

2. Founders teach you more than you teach them. Gotta accept it. Despite being a founder in the past, the drive of new founders I meet constantly reminds how much more there is to learn and unlearn.

3. Finding the founder who has the skin in the game is hard. But those who have the most to lose are a better bet to take than those whose life won’t change even if they lose everything.

4. Slow progress is still a million times better than no progress.

5. If you get an update from the founder and you are not asking the right questions, you are learning nothing.

6. Founders with very high expectations usually have very low patience.

7. Rejection can be delivered in many ways and will often hurt the founder. But a rejection with a reason & feedback on what they are building is better than a diplomatic no.

8. It is impossible to be helpful and opinionated at the same time.

9. We can either trust our gut or intellect to make a decision. It’s a choice between being happy or being right. Figuring each is hard work.

10. The paradox of autonomy. I’d imagined being a startup investor would give me control over my time, only to find myself constantly on the clock dealing with founders and their emotions at all hours.

11. Asking for company updates means you care about the business. Asking for the founder’s wellbeing means you care about them. Finding the right balance will make a true cheerleader.

12. The number of times “I” is used instead of “We” on emails will tell if the founder cares about their team.

13. There is a thin line between being bold and being reckless. We can predict it but can’t anticipate it.

14. The most important metric for an investor to the founder should be “being useful”. This is what Nithin was for me when I was a founder.

I wanted to make this list count till 18 but this is all i've got :)

https://lnkd.in/gP6i-xtw

posted_at: {'date': '2024-08-07 06:38:55', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1723005535771}
text:
There is something about Sports that drives emotions. Even if you don’t play it. Even if you don’t follow it. 

29yo wrestler fought two battles. Against a dominant and some say an unbeatable opponent. But that was just a physical fight. She came here fighting millions of naysayers and critics whom did a lot to pull her down. She had a torn ligament. A lower weight category. And she is the first Indian now to make to an Olympics finals. That’s Vinesh Phogat for you. She is not done yet. 

A 22yo shuttler becomes first Indian to get to Olympics semi finals. He gave a good fight but couldn’t come home with a medal. The coach feels, he could have done more on the court. But people are rooting for this kid. That’s Lakshya Sen for you.

15 men went on a mission to reclaim the lost glory of Indian hockey. Made it to semi finals  of Olympics and fought a hard battle. They couldn’t get through to a gold but stirred a lot of emotions in a country who had forgotten the sport. That’s Indian national hockey team for you. They are not done yet. 

There are numerous more emotions.

There is one thing you all should do. Tell your kids these stories of grit and resilience. Show them these emotions. They will learn from real sports. Movies can wait.

A country is built on the back of many such athletes. We are animals of emotions.

text:
Employee health & fitness shouldn’t be complicated. It should be simple and it should be a culture.

We had a random internal chat on world record for push-ups. And decided to check how many we can do in a minute. This is a video from that 😊

No HR was involved. There was no cash prize, no incentives, no leaderboard. No one was forced but most chose to do.

Employee health shouldn’t be limited to one yoga day or world health day. It should be a regular conversation. It should be driven by everyone from top to bottom. Don’t over engineer it with too many wellness programs. Keep it simple. Make it a culture. 

Zerodha | Rainmatter by Zerodha

posted_at: {'date': '2024-07-31 06:58:40', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1722401920663}
text:
Met a 65yo aspiring entrepreneur this week. A grandmom to four kids who wants to solve a problem most in this current generation maybe facing. 

Her problem statement: In India every minute 51 babies are born. That means 26,805,600 couples become parent every year. That's 26.8 million couples. Parenting is not a skill that is taught and is a stressful journey for the first 5 years. Especially for working couples with no support.

Solution: A therapy/counselling service just focused on new parents. They are stressed and confused most of the time. They need someone to guide them and tell what not to do than what to do. 

Her competitive edge : Mother to three and grandmom to four kids. I can’t create an app but can attempt to create mindful parents. This is what she said :) 

Being an entrepreneur late in life can be a superpower. Because you've outlived the fads and fanciness. Now, it's all about substance and genuine awareness. Experience and wisdom are the dividends of a well-lived life.

Sharing the first message she sent me on Twitter in the comments 😊

posted_at: {'date': '2024-07-19 06:31:52', 'relative': '1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1721363512179}
text:
Met a mother & daughter this week. Entrepreneurs solving for Autism. Why? Because 1 in every 63 children in India has the risk of Autism. They were not the typical startup founders talking AI & tech.

Spent 1hr+ together and not once they spoke about market potential, competition or business strategy. They were obsessed with the problem and how their solution solves for it. Autism is the world’s most common developmental disorder in children. Yet big healthcare providers are not focused enough to solve for that. 

Why will people come to you, i asked? Mother said- "My younger daughter had autism and I trained myself as a speech language therapist to provide care to my own daughter. My goal is to make mothers, their child's best therapist and hospitals don't want to do that". 

Entrepreneurs who solve for their own problems with relentless passion are unstoppable.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-07-18 06:49:33', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1721278173443}
text:
If you are new to exercising or thinking to get started. There is an unspoken truth which you should know about fitness routines. 

This applies if you are going to a gym, yoga , meditate or want to get out and run. 

The first workout in the gym will be hard.
The first run on the road will be hard.
The first 2 mins of meditation will be hard. 
Adaptions take time. Recovery will be slow .

And there will be a constant internal debate- why the hell I’m doing this again. 
It’s boring. It’s not easy. 
Everyone struggles. I struggle. 

Then slowly, fitness compounds. 
Week after week.
Set short goals. 
And you will get meaningful progress.
Hard workouts will give a sense of achievement. Easy workouts will become enjoyable. 

Accept that there is no hack to fitness. 
Consistency will shrink the gap between the goal and progress
Just show up every day. It's boring but the gains will come as compounding benefits.

Fitness training is just learning to be bored while you're hurting. And finding pleasure in the small gains.

Took me 6years to reinvent the different me. 
It was slow and boring. But here I am.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-07-12 06:33:22', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1720758802283}
text:
There is a common pattern in abandoning yourself as a founder. I'll tell you what i was doing so you could avoid that. And I realised this after closing my startup and now being a cheerleader to others. 

1) Not apologising to team members or partners when I owe them an apology. 
2) Saying “yes” to every opportunity when I was aching to focus on core product.
3) Over-explaining my vision to investors who stopped listening a long time ago.
4) Begging for investor attention without demanding respect. 
5) Building a company based on what I think looks “successful” rather than what actually solves problems.
6) Neglecting my health and well-being. Burning out by overworking. 
7) Twisting my values to fit into industry trends I’ve outgrown.
8) Refusing to accept the reality of my startup. Lying to myself about my progress. 
9) Celebrating those who only tolerate my efforts.
10) Not allowing time for deep rest to myself and others and running on fumes

Wishing I was someone else. 
There are 104 million entrepreneurs in India. If you are one of them save yourself
https://x.com/kmr_dilip

posted_at: {'date': '2024-07-08 07:35:39', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1720416939558}
text:
India plays cricket. And cricket makes money. Can that money be used to fuel other sports? 

BCCI earned 16,875 crore($2billion) last year. And it has 30 players under active contract. 

These 30 players are collectively paid 88 crore as salary annually. Ofcourse they earn in mutiples outside of this pay. 

So, there is a massive amount of surplus money that the BCCI has. Even after their work expenses. 

Indian government allocated 3396 crore last year as sports budget. And we still have Olympic players who are struggling to meet their expenses. Some don’t have money to travel to tournaments. 

Imagine if the surplus money from one organisation could be used to fuel and support talent of other sports. 

It’s a wishful thinking. But we have to find ways to get support to other deserving athletes. We’ve so much potential.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-07-06 06:44:39', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1720241079371}
text:
There is one health advice you will never hear from anyone. You can go to gym and build muscles, you can train to run and become a marathoner , you can get your 4ltr of water everyday, you can get your 7hrs of sleep , you can get all the superfoods and supplements. 

But if you don’t learn to deal the chaos in your head and bullshit people around you, you’re still going to be unhealthy. 

You can’t change the people around you. But you can change the people around you. 

Ignoring some people for your mental health is not a weakness. It is your superpower. 
Make your mental health your first priority.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-07-03 06:35:43', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1719981343324}
text:
Just a reminder. 950 new startups were launched last year. But 35,000 startups were shut down. If you want to build a company, you’ve just one very important decision to make. 

No matter what else you do, you should figure out this first. You don't have to go to an accelerator, incubator or a VC for this. 

The decision whether to grow slowly, organically and profitably or to have a big bang with fast growth, lots of capital and burn. 

I ignored making that decision when i was building. Irony is, I'm now reminding others when they come for funding :) 

Valuation and funding are just the shiny toys. If you really want to play, focus on your customers and making a profit. Toys break, but a good business lasts and you will be in the game for long.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-07-01 07:10:26', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1719810626797}
text:
India won the cricket world cup. That's great. But for us to be a sporting nation there is a lot more to be done. You may not know this, India has won only 35 Olympic medals in 122 years. China won 634 medals in 32 years.

India's sports budget last year was 3397 crore. China spent 26,240 crore. We spend 3 paisa per capita per day on sports. And China spends 6 rupees. That’s 200 times more than us.

Both countries have similar population size. Yet India is the lowest in the world on medals per capita. 

We may be brilliant in cricket. But if we've to be a sporting country, we've to spend and support other sports. Watch and celebrate other sports and athletes just the way we do for cricket. We have a lot of talent and potential in other sports to win medals. 

Government may do their work. But we've to also chip in. If you work in a corporate ask your CSR team to support sports and other athletes. Less than 2% of CSR spends are on sports. Consider other athletes in your marketing campaigns. They have a story to share. 

At Rainmatter by Zerodha we will do our part. Hope you will do yours. 
And encourage kids around you to play more sports.

text:
AI & ChatGPT will not solve for this. You have to. Becoming unfit is not an event. It is a process.

-Prioritise physical activity. Nothing is more important.
-Eat healthy. Don’t be the profit machine to processed & packaged industry.

Your only goal should be to be in your kids & partners life as long as you can.

Like loosing money, loosing your health is rarely caused by one thing going wrong. Usually, it is a series of ignorance and wrong doings. Take control now.

If you wait until you're motivated, you’ve already lost.

text:
Two rules every startup employee should follow.
Rule #1: Never stop questioning your founder. 
Rule #2 : Never forget rule #1. 

Transperancy in work culture should be the perk you should boast. If you don’t have it, the founder doesn’t deserve you. Growth is hindered when you don’t understand the reasons behind what is expected of you and why. 

There are more than 2million startup employees in India. Not being afraid to challenge one another’s assumption will get the best for you , your company and your colleagues.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-06-24 06:50:24', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1719204624568}
text:
Bring a bunch of founders under one roof, let them talk to each other, give no gyaan. And magic will happen. Last Friday was this. 
Did an impromptu Health Founders meet-up in Delhi last Friday. 180+ people signed up. Could only admit 40 due to space limitations. All of them showed up and few brought their co-founders along.

I thought events and meet-ups were in abundance. Maybe 5-10 people will turn up. But 50 founders were hanging out for 4 hrs on a Friday evening. And all passionate about health and building products to make Indians healthy. 

There was no speech, no panel, no agenda. 
But entrepreneurs have an innate ability to communicate. So they all started talking to each other. Figured that networking is overrated. But a space to have unfiltered conversations and be your authentic is underrated. 

Some got new customers.
Some met their customers who were using their products. 
Some got offer to share the office space.
Some validated their new product ideas.
Some established new partnerships. 
Lot of questions on why, what and how. 
And a few made their funding pitch. Founder preamble you know :) 
There was learning and a some unlearning. 

Apologies for people we couldn’t admit. There was a genuine space limitation. 
It was an experiment and i dint expect this much response. 

At Rainmatter our credo is to add meaningful support to the ecosystem. 
Either through capital allocation or cheering for entrepreneurs. 
Should we do this more often? In other cities?

posted_at: {'date': '2024-06-15 07:48:20', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1718430500342}
text:
I’m often asked if valuations and funding in startups have any impact to the business of the company. Some unpopular thoughts.

Startup funding didn't create massive losses; it simply highlighted who the real loss-makers are.

High valuations didn't make founders overpromise; they just revealed who the true overpromisers are.

Startup valuations didn't inflate founders' egos; They just showed us who already had overinflated egos.

Massive funding rounds didn't cause founders to burn cash; they just showed us who the real cash-burners are.

Sky-high valuations didn't make startups unsustainable; they just pointed out which ones were unsustainable from the start.

Venture funding didn't lead to unrealistic projections; it just exposed who was already dreaming too big.

Reality will always find its way of exposing the truth behind the myths.

text:
There are two type of VC’s.
I learnt it the hard way. You should know this.

Investors who ping to ask for company updates. They care about the business. 
Investors who ping to ask about your wellbeing. They care about you, the founder. 

Figuring out when you need whom is the founders journey.

The difference between a good VC and a great one is that a good VC is concerned more about the outcome while a great one is fascinated by the process of learning through the founder.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-06-10 07:53:52', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1717998832442}
text:
It’s Monday morning. Most of us are getting to work while some of our athletes did their work putting Indian on global map. Served a reminder that winning when your odds are against you is a superpower. And i’m not talking about cricket.  

Puja Tomar became the first Indian to win a fight at UFC. And this was her debut match. From a family of farmers in UP she lost her father at young age and took up mixed martial sports at age six for self-defense and empowerment. Won many medals for India and is a six time national Wushu champion. 

“I decided to let people say whatever they wanted. It just made me practice harder to show them that girls can do martial arts and they don’t depend on men.” This is Puja saying why she does combat sports. 

Sanjivani Jadhav won the 10,000m at Portland Track meet in US finishing in 32 mins 22 secs. That’s 3min & 14 sec/ kilometre for 10km. Most of us can’t run 100m at that pace. And she won this competing against world class athletes and Olympians. Last year she dint have any financial support and had to pay for her training in US to prepare for the Asian Champs where she won Bronze. No support from federation or anyone. 

Sumit Nagal is currently India no. 1 singles player in tennis and yesterday won the Heilbronner Neckarcup ATP challenger. This is a big win and gives him a chance to go to Paris Olympics next month. 

Earlier this year he just had bank balance of less than Rs. 80,000 and was struggling to get financial support. He is now back in the circuit winning and competing against the best in the game. 

Why these win matters? Why such athletes matters? 
A sport like MMA is a brutal. Just getting inside the octagon needs superhuman mental and physical strengths. 
Tennis and Athletics has to be more than Roger Federer and Usain Bolt of us. It’s easier to create life lessons from these global stars. Much harder to talk about our own athletes because our own media and community doesn’t talk about them. Grit and determination is a common fuel every athlete survives on. Some make it to stardom others continue to fight out every day.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-06-07 07:01:44', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1717736504151}
text:
She said “Winning a gold for India is my ultimate goal”
You should know more about this talented para athlete.

This is Sheetal Devi. The first armless female archer in the world and shoots using her legs and feet.

Sheetal was born without hands (Phocomelia) a rare congenital disorder leading to underdeveloped limbs. This means difficulties in performing everyday tasks like eating, dressing, and writing. She had to develop her own techniques using her legs and feet. Growing up, she said “Mujhey bhi kuch karna hai”

In 2019, Sheetal caught the attention of the Indian Army during the youth games in J&K. The coaches and the family tried to get a prosthetic arm but it didn't fit. Sheetal competed in able-bodied category at the Under-18 level and won multiple medals. 

In 2022, at age 16, she won two gold medals and one silver at the Asian Para Games, becoming the first Indian woman to win two golds at the event. 

In 2023, she won a silver medal at the World Archery Para Championships, becoming the first armless female archer to medal at the event.

She is an Arjuna award winner and her ultimate goal is to win a Paralympic gold medal for India.

Remember this name Sheetal Devi at Paris Paralympics in few months. 
She is currently supported by the team at Olympic gold Quest.

I will continue to share about our athletes going for Olympics & Paralympics this year. They are not expecting that. But if we don't do that, their hard work and grit will go unnoticed. Maybe you should also.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-06-06 06:55:12', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1717649712613}
text:
I spend all my time at the intersection of health and startups. Figuring good health and enduring companies. There are few things that are overrated and common in both. 

1) Hype- “AI” in startups or “biohack” in health. Buzzwords attract attention but doesn't guarantee outcome. When the hype fades, the reality remains. Stay away from the temptation to get attention, focus on what drives outcome. 

2) Spending for quick outcome: Crazy spend to chase growth or splurging on longevity protocols. Money can’t buy meaningful success, only the illusion of it.

3) Obsession with numbers: High valuations in startups or obsessive tracking of health metrics. This obsession will lead to value the measurable over the meaningful. 

4) Extreme approaches: Rapid growth at all costs in startups or extreme diets and workout routines in health. Extremes are seldom the answer, they’re usually the problem.

5) Features : Overloading your product with features or your body with supplements. Keep it simple is hard, no one can do it. Making it complicated is easy, everyone can do it.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-06-01 06:01:05', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1717214465243}
text:
I meet entrepreneurs all the time. I’ve been one myself and now cheering them from the other side. There are two things that stands out in most of my interaction. 


First , If you want to be an entrepreneur , build the muscle to do things that most can't and don't want to do. You will be alone in doing that and you’ve have to accept it. 

Second, becoming an entrepreneur and getting successful as an entrepreneur are two different skills. 

Becoming an entrepreneur requires taking risks, being optimistic and putting yourself out there.
But getting successful as an entrepreneur requires the opposite of taking risk. It requires humility and fear that what you've made can be taken away from you just as fast or can be criticised by strangers. It requires frugality and an acceptance that at least some of what you've made is attributable to luck.

text:
Behind every star athlete or a champion there is a supporting family. 
Parents who teach their kids that success is not about winning but how well they can recover when they fall. 

This is Nagalakshmi. An unassuming mother of two young Indian chess prodigies Praggnanandhaa and Vaishali. The first-ever brother-sister duo to both earn the Grand master title. Today both of them are well known for their achievements in the sport. Most don’t know that their mother, Nagalakshmi accompanies them to tournaments for encouragement and support. Father Rameshbabu works as a branch manager at TNSC Bank and is honest to say they were facing financial constraints but were determined to support both their kids. 

I’ve now spent time with Olympians, World champions & India no.1 on my podcast and a common thread amongst all of them is their early childhood and the parental support all of them had.  The most important economic decisions a society makes are not made in corporate offices, but in homes.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-05-22 05:24:12', 'relative': '1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1716348252132}
text:
That's Mariyappan Thangavelu. Just few hours back he won India's 🇮🇳 first ever Gold Medal in High Jump at World Para Athletics. Media won't share stories of such incredible athletes. But you should know more about him.

At the age of 5, he met with an accident where a drunk bus driver ran over his right leg that permanently disabled his knee. His school physical education teacher encouraged him to try high jump and he excelled at it. 

Comes from a humble background, he was was raised by a single mother working as a daily wage labourer and vegetable seller to support the family. 

Despite this setback, he completed his schooling and earned a bachelor's degree in business administration. 

At the 2016 Rio Paralympics, he won the gold medal for India. In 2020 Tokyo Paralympics he could have won the gold again but the rains made the conditions difficult and settled for a silver.

He is a Padma Shri and Arjuna Award winner. And won the Dhyan Chand Khel Ratna award in 2020 which is India's highest sporting honor.

He used all his prize money to buy a paddy field for his mother and built a better house for his family. 

Mariyappan believes that his right deformed big toe helps him to get the leap. “This is what gives me leverage when I jump,” he says. “It is my God.”

India is a country of amazing sporting talent. But we also need to be a country to celebrate all sports athletes. Everyone doesn't get brand deals and sponsors. The only fuel for these athletes is their grit and determination. Our only job is to cheer them and share their stories.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-05-19 07:48:16', 'relative': '1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1716097696444}
text:
The paradox of a common man. Most of us go through this. Few know what to do and they do it. Others don’t, but that is ok too. 

1. The Paradox of Freedom: Do a startup to be your own boss and work whenever you want, which turns out to be all the time. Or, get a corporate job and have your work hours dictated, but at least you can leave work at the office (most of the time).

2. The Paradox of Security: Choose a stable corporate job for financial security, yet constantly worry about layoffs and office politics. Or go for a startup where the thrill of potential success keeps you up at night, along with the fear of financial ruin.

3. The Paradox of Passion: Follow your passion by starting a business, only to realize passion doesn’t pay the bills. Or, take a well-paying corporate job and spend your evenings fantasizing about your dream business.

4. The Paradox of Expertise: In a corporate job, you’ll be the go-to expert in a very narrow field. As an entrepreneur, you’ll know a little about a lot and be an expert in juggling crises.

5. The Paradox of Stability: A corporate job offers a steady paycheck and clear career path, leading to midlife crises and existential dread. A startup offers unpredictable income and career path, leading to daily crises and existential dread.

6. The Paradox of Recognition: In a corporate job, your hard work might get recognized… by your boss taking credit. In a startup, every little success is yours to celebrate… if you have the time and energy to do so.

7. The Paradox of Work-Life Balance: Corporate jobs promise work-life balance with paid vacations you might never take. Startups offer the flexibility to work from anywhere, which really means working everywhere, all the time.

8. The Paradox of Learning: At a corporate job, you’ll attend endless training sessions on things you already know. As an entrepreneur, every mistake is a costly but valuable lesson, with no formal training required.

The reality of the rat race is that even if we win the race, we are still a rat.
https://x.com/kmr_dilip
