text:
I’m often asked how large is the Indian sports and fitness market in India? I don’t have a perfect research on it. But if you want to build something here is how you should look at it.


Top 5 sports brands in India had a collective revenue of over 11,500 crores in FY 23.
Decathlon- 4000 cr
Puma- 3000Cr
Adidas- 2600 cr
Skechers 1800 cr
ASICS- 345 cr
All nos. are rounded off. 

-Two year ago these brands had a combined sales of 5000cr.
-All of them grew 35-60% YOY.
-And these are just 5 brands.There are so many more in the market.
-Assume 15-20% spends are on non-sports /fitness products.
A sizeable 15,000Cr+ might have been spent on sports brands alone.

That’s how much people have spent to stay active. It could be running shoes, athletic apparels, sports or fitness gears.

These are the same people who are more likely to spend on 
-Playing at sports facilities
-Eat the right food and will need nutrition coaching
-Conscious to healthier alternatives to eat and drink
-And aware of overall wellbeing including mental health and sleep.

So just go and build something. There is always a market if you build the right product for the right audience and solve for their problem. And help them measure their progress.

text:
This is a scary data. Breast Cancer screening in India is 1.9% against 82% in USA, 70% in UK and 23% in China.

Most common cancers in order of occurrence in India are Breast, Cervix and Ovary in women. One woman gets diagnosed with breast cancer every 4 minutes in India, and one woman dies of breast cancer every 13 minutes. 

Typically it costs inr 5-15k. It can be an affordability issue but not for Tier1 cities. 

The common feedback I’ve got is
1) lack of awareness 
2) the fear of positive result hence avoid
3) concern of false positive diagnosis and undergoing unnecessary biopsy. 

What can be done to make screening more accessible and increase awareness? 
Or accessibility is not the issue here?

posted_at: {'date': '2024-04-17 09:39:00', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1713339540620}
text:
I was asked to tell kids graduating from college on what an ideal professional life is. And the role of luck & risk in it. I made these slides. 


Slide 1
Ideal life: Startup work culture + Corporate salary + Govt job perks.

Slide 2
Whoever promises the above. They are a scamster. Don't fall for it 😊

Slide 3
The hardest thing in the world is to understand the gap between luck & risk. 

Slide 4
Luck + Risk = growth. Figuring out the appropriate dose of each is key, and a moving target.

Slide 5
Luck & Risk are two underrated assets. What you do with it matters.
How much you have should not matter.

I think solving for WHY will unlock new market opportunities . 
How & What will get you first time customer.

If the HRV dropped, we should know what caused it.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-04-09 06:31:02', 'relative': '1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1712637062012}
text:
Most people are afraid of sharing their own thoughts online. One of the biggest mistake people think is that they have to be an "expert" to share about something. I'll explain. 

The truth is, people don't want to learn from experts. They prefer to learn from those just a few steps ahead of them on the same path. And once you realise this, it's a huge creative unlock. You might connect with like-minded individuals, but that's just a bonus.

If you are a founder or a builder of any kind, share your experiences and learnings from the projects you did. Share how you cracked a new growth channel, how you managed retaining talent, how you got the first few enterprise customers, how you built the first version of the product, how you got investors to back you, how you manage your board meetings. Just open source your playbook. 

If you share what you do, how you think, how you solve problems, and who you can help, the Internet will introduce you to lots of people who value you!

You don’t need hash tags, cute bullet icons or post your own picture with a coffee mug looking outside the window. Don’t fall for people who promise you followers and personal branding tips and sell you courses. 

You are not writing for others, you are writing for your own mental clarity.
Don't overthink, write , share and good things will happen.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-04-03 07:16:51', 'relative': '1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1712121411933}
text:
Some trends that can create interesting opportunities to build a health business in India. More details below.


First- Gaming industry 
-India is the largest gaming market in the world today. 
-We’ve an estimate 568 million gamers. 40% are women. 
-Mobile contributes to 90 per cent of the gaming market

So what’s the health opportunity?
-3.5% of Indian adolescents suffer from Internet Gaming Disorder (IGD). 
-Excessive gaming (> 4hr/day) is one of primary causes to musculoskeletal pain
-Approx 17% gamers report psychosomatic symptoms like nervousness, irritation, headache, and sleep problems.
-Excessive gaming leads to isolation, neglect of real-life relationships, and a higher risk of depression and social anxiety.

Create product and solutions specifically for gamers. 
20% of gamers in India are paying users. So there is a sizeable market that will pay for solutions. Build partnerships with gaming companies. They would want their MAU & DAU to be active & growing.


Second- Education Industry
-Approx 17 lakh students appear for class 12 exams in India every year.
-Approx 20 lakh students sit of various combined competitive exams every year
-Approx 13 lakh students prepare for UPSC prelims every year. 
-Over 2 lakh students go to Kota every year away from their home to prepare for JEE and NEET. 

So what’s the health opportunity?
-Nearly 50 million Indian children suffer from mental disorders at any given time.
-National Mental Health survey estimates approximately 23% school & college going children in India have psychiatric disorders. This includes anxiety and stress. 

Create product and solutions specifically for students. 
-Parents are the customer. Students are the users. There is a growing awareness amongst educators and parents on mental health.
-Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) offers a tele-consuelling support to students in managing stress and anxiety. But that's not enough.
-Ministry of Education has laid comprehensive guidelines to safeguard the mental and emotional well-being of students. But Schools and colleges doesn't quite know how to implement them.
-Build partnerships with schools, colleges and edutech companies.

I shared some more opportunities in health here https://lnkd.in/gn6ibaGj

If you are building something to help Indians stay healthy both physically and mentally. Happy to connect and chat.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-03-19 06:24:16', 'relative': '1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1710825856163}
text:
An unpopular opinion about founders/VC's building and investing in health category. This may disappoint a few.

First, if you are a founder building in the health. You've to walk the talk. 
What does that mean? You have to be healthy and fit. 

-The biggest moat in the health industry is trust. This can't be built by performance marketing or hiring influencers. 
-Why will a customer trust your product if the founder isn't healthy? You don't need six packs. But you shouldn't look unfit.
-If your product came out from your own problem statement, great. Tell the world how you got there and share your experience. 
-In health industry you scale by not selling features. But by earning the trust. 

Second, don't pitch or raise money from an investor who doesn't walk the talk. 

-To build a scalable business TAM is important. But impact is most important.
- If the first question they ask is, how large is the business and not why you choose to build the product. That's a sign.
- If an investor doesn't make an effort to experience your product or service and offer genuine feedback. They are truly not investing in you. But chasing vanity.
- Have seen many VC events ending with alcohol and the food corner filled with junk. And that happens because they don't walk the talk and perhaps staying healthy is not their top priority in personal life. 

That's it. Hope this changes. And we build businesses and products that brings impact on people. And trust is your anchor to scale.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-03-17 05:46:53', 'relative': '1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1710650813602}
text:
In 2020, I set a goal to run my first Sub 3hr marathon. This was my mental & physical training playbook. 


For 4months, I was chasing this goal. 
It was up on my wall. 
To become Sub 3 marathoner. 
I was a 3:00:25 runner till then. 

𝗠𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗠𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹 #𝟭
These lofty goals look far and hazy in the begining. But you gotta keep chasing them. Every day, every week, every month.

And every week, I got two inch closer.

𝗠𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗠𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹 #𝟮
I’ll wake up and stare at the wall looking at all the past training and before going to bed manifest whatever left for the next day.

𝗠𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗠𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹 #𝟯
Marathon training is just learning to be bored while you're hurting. Embrace it. 

𝗠𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗠𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹 #𝟰
On race day, I finished 2:59:52. 
But those 16 weeks changed me a lot.
as a friend,
as a runner,
as a partner,
and as a human.

𝗠𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗠𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹 #𝟱
Everyone teaches motivation. 
But no one learns discipline.
Motivation is in abundance. 
Discipline is scarce.

𝗠𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗠𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹 #𝟲
The progress in your goals is the gap between your desire and commitment.

𝗠𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹 𝗠𝗼𝗱𝗲𝗹 #7
Running a marathon will teach you 42 times more about yourself than an expensive self help course. 

This is the exact running training plan i followed to become a Sub3hr marathoner first time. Not that anyone should follow this. But just incase.

I put all my training on Strava https://lnkd.in/eumPX5w

text:
If you read this in a resume, hire them. If you are looking for a job, it's ok to write it. It’s not a weakness. It’s a superpower. 

"I was at a toxic work culture. I couldn’t handle it anymore and quit"

"I was burnt out and took time to fix my mental and physical health."

"I took a break because i wanted to spend time with my ageing parents."

"I’m a mom/dad and took a break to spend time with my child. We played and learnt new things."

"I was confused and wanted to pause. I spent time travelling, reading books and figuring out what next."

"I was a founder and did everything to stay relevant and exist. But we couldn’t. My startup failed, but i haven’t."

"I’m a mother who chose to take a break after maternity. It’s been a while i worked and i want to do something meaningful."

These are people who have a strong decision matrix. 
Taking a break should be normalised. 

It’s ok, if we don’t know what we want. 
It’s important to know what we don’t want.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-03-11 07:38:44', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1710139124716}
text:
To all founders raising money from investors. Don’t do this. 


1) Don’t use dollar for your funding ask and use INR for valuation. Have a uniformity in your numbers. 

2) Don’t send password protected decks and expect the investor to generate a password from another link. Don’t add more friction to the review process. 

3) Your follower count on Instagram is not equal to business traction. Don’t add that on your growth slide. 

4) Don’t add stock images and random quotes as customer testimonials. Genuinity matters. Have seen the same customer face three times in a day on different decks.

5) On your growth slide, elaborate the metrics you are tracking. Don’t assume everyone understands the abbreviations you are using. 

6) Don’t assume everyone uses Microsoft teams and add that in the calendar invite. Ask for preference. 

7) Don’t put your consultants names as founding members. It’s ok if you are two founders and a few interns.

8) If you are an early stage company (< 2-3cr ARR), avoid vision and mission statements. Put more thought on the problem statement, your solution and why that matters.

9) If you want to show a market trend or data. Don’t just mention “sources”.  Add the actual reference on the slide. 

10) Don’t use chat GPT for your email intro. Those are very evident. 

It’s your company. It’s your passion. Be honest in everything you share and say.
That is a founder moat.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-03-07 05:04:10', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1709784250657}
text:
We celebrate women’s day every year. But have we asked women if it really benefits them? 


Don’t get me wrong. I am not denouncing Women’s Day. 

Look around your meeting room, how many women are there?
How many women do you see in your gym or running on the roads?

World economic forum ranks India 127th out of 146 countries in terms of gender parity. 

48% of Indian women leave the workforce within four months of their return from maternity leave. 

25% of women in India face mental health issues which is twice the rate compared to men.

23 million girls in India drop out of school annually due to a lack of proper menstrual hygiene facilities.

There were no leadership lessons shared on Linkedin when Indian women badminton team won the Asian team championships last month. 

Women’s Day should not be a lip service or a marketing campaign to drive sales and make trendy social media post. There shouldn’t be 364 days of inaction after just one day of celebration. 

What should we do? 

First accept that there is inequality, and then support them. Help the women in our life every day and become a responsible adult. Don’t stereotype them to domestic roles. 

If you - whether a man or a woman, spot someone saying something sexist about another woman, speak up. Whether its a WhatsApp group, social circle or at workplace. 

Learn to respect consent and boundaries. Every woman might have a different one. 

So to all the brands, companies and men going to celebrate Women's Day. Do it for the other 364 days as well. 

Women’s day is a reminder but our actions every day should be the alarm.

text:
We invested in a flour making company. Here's why.
Roti/Chapati is a staple food for most regions in India after rice. 


The avg consumption is 6kg of wheat/month/person. 
15% of India currently buys packaged wheat flour spending approx $2 billion every year. 

But most of the rotis or breads we eat lacks the basic nutrient values. The typical wheat we mill ourselves or buy from supermarkets, is not as nutritious as we assume. Because most of the nutrients in the wheat grains are lost during the grinding process. Since a substantial portion of the population relies on wheat flour for their dietary needs. We wanted to explore if there can be a healthier alternative to existing flour options. 

At Rainmatter we want to create an ecosystem of products and brands that are healthier alternatives for Indians. We are excited to partner with Pranjal Y Kumar and Arjun Rungta co-founders at TWF Flours. They are working on techniques to ensure the maximum amount of nutrition is retained during the milling process. 

Here is a detailed post of the announcment and a note from the founders on what they are building and why https://lnkd.in/gi6B7222

posted_at: {'date': '2024-02-28 07:13:51', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1709100831034}
text:
Okay, about the recent post by Nithin and all the crazy theories being spread around – there are a few things people should know.

First, I work with Nithin closely. We have done workouts and races together. I know him a little more than others making opinions and commentary on social media. 

So, what should be the takeaway from his post?
 
Being fit is not equal to being healthy. Most people believe being healthy and being fit are one and the same. It’s not. They are not synonymous and are distinct states of physical well-being. 

Being fit means your ability to perform physical activities such as endurance, stamina, strength, flexibility, power & speed. These are a set of attributes that people have or develop to perform a physical activity. 

Being healthy is a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being. Your physiological and internal biological systems should be working in harmony. 

We often look at athletes or movie stars as fit and healthy. But often they are not. If you want to understand the science, read this https://lnkd.in/g_rT5gMM

You may be a runner, go to gym regularly or get your ten thousand daily steps. Fitness doesn't guarantee health. While being fit can contribute to overall health, it's possible for someone to be physically fit but still experience health issues due to poor nutrition, stress, lack of sleep, or underlying medical conditions. 

We all live a hectic life and are exposed to stress and distractions all the time. It’s even more important for people who prioritize fitness to balance it with healthy living. Stress + rest = growth. 

Going to a gym or doing a run doesn’t get you a heart attack or stroke. 
Overdoing it might. So do everything in the right proportion. 

1- Get your blood tests done at regular intervals. 
2- Consult your physician. Not your WhatsApp friends. 
3- Seek help from a qualified nutritionist and trainer. Not Instagram or YouTube influencers.
4- Spend less time doing commentary on Whatsapp groups and more with your family and friends.  
 
The gap between being healthy and looking fit is a modern-day confusion caused by social media. 

Fitness is important and can be achieved through specific physical activities.
Health considers various dimensions of well-being and is achieved by sustainable long-term practices. 
Striking a balance between both is real work.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-02-15 07:13:20', 'relative': '1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1707977600635}
text:
I think there two massive opportunities in health that is perfect to build now. 
First -A McKinsey for personalised health for India.   
Second- A Mixpanel for your health data.  More details here ⬇ 

1️⃣ So what’s the McKinsey of personalised health? 
Think of it as a high touch subscription membership that includes 
-Blood work
-Vo2, Dexa scan , Genetic testing , Food allergic testing
-For females specific tests - Hormonal, epigenetic & more. 
- Personal nutritionist 
- Meals sent to you based on your macros & calories. 
- Personal trainer for exercise programming.  
- Recovery & sleep intervention based on weekly stressors by an expert. 
- Mental health coach. 
- Personalised recommendations on dietary & macro/micro nutrient supplements. And the products are shipped every month. 
- Regular checkin by a physician who operates on functional medicine & recommends based on health data. 
- Monthly reviews on lifestyle parameters, performance & longevity analysis by a dedicated health coach. 

➡️ Thinking this as a Peter Attia equivalent for India. Is the TAM >1 million users? Maybe not. But there is an opportunity to build a $10million company in 5-7 years. Not a super scalable service but a premium and hands on service that can have good margins and grow 10-15%+ YOY. 

2️⃣ What’s Mixpanel for health data
A digital dashboard that gives daily/weekly/monthly insights of your body’s performance.
-Tracks your Sleep , RHR, Steps, HRV, Skin temperature from your wearables 
-Gives a well rounded score of your health cadence basis your goal.
-Captures your nutritional info and shows what you missed and what you overdid. 
-Captures your fitness activity and grades your body’s response. 
-Captures your body measurements and tracks weekly changes. 
-Captures your physiological markers and tracks changes. 
- Crates a summary for your physician, trainer or nutritionist. 
- Add an AI assistant that answers your specific questions based on your data. 

➡️ This can be a global product. A DIY software tool built by a solid product, engineering, design, data and clinical science team. Can be sold like a subscription tool. I feel there is an opportunity to build a $100million global company. 

Who is building this? Or wants to build? Reach out if you are interested.
Have a ton of wishlist and notes to share and brainstorm.  
Have been at the crossroad as an enthusiast and supporter for these solutions.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-02-13 05:41:32', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1707799292112}
text:
Let’s raise children who can name fruits , vegetables & plants, not celebrities & YouTube channels.


Children are not reading this. But you are. 

These are news headlines today. Will become national emergency soon. But will start from our home. 

Don’t complicate yourself by figuring out what’s the best thing to do for your kids. Start with basics.

1) Encourage movement. Could be sports, exercise or just simple walks. 
2) Avoid packaged or processed foods. Kids get excited seeing their favourite sports star on the package. But these are just actors paid to do their job. Explain this to them. Importantly as parent, you should walk the talk and avoid processed food. 
3)Minimize device time. Get them to nature. Simple hikes & treks are a good starting point. 

Seek guidance or help from experts. School, play school, nanny will do their job. But your your child’s health is your responsibility.

posted_at: {'date': '2024-01-17 05:25:37', 'relative': '1 year ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1705465537974}
text:
If you are running the Tata Mumbai Marathon this weekend. This is for you.
Running a marathon will teach you 42 times more about yourself than an expensive self help course.


This is the story of Sifan Hassan's remarkable win at London Marathon last year. 

-Within one hour of the race, she fell off the pace from the lead pack.
-She was struggling with pain and stopped twice to stretch her hips.
-For elite runners when they stop in a marathon their chances of winning is almost zero.

At this time the commentators said "She needs to stop and somebody needs to give her advice to step off and stop trying to run on. She may not know what to do in a marathon".

-But Sifan showed grit & resilience to stay on the course limping while her competitors raced ahead of her.
-At one point, she was nearly hit by the lead motorbike while trying to get to her water bottle.
-Later she offered water to her rivals.
-With every kilometre she closed the gap with the leaders and soon was with the pack.
-And 400meters away from the finish line she surged leaving her competition almost impossible to catch her.

Sifan won the race with a finish time of 2hr 18min 34 sec

After the finish she said “I learned to be patient and just to run my own race. Just keep going as much as possible and maybe i'll surprise myself.”

Remember:
Becoming strong is not an event. It's a process.
Discipline is remembering what you want.
Stay patient, pace yourself well. 
The race begins when your mind starts giving up. 

Good luck for a strong finish!

text:

Seek guidance to educate yourself. Don’t outsource your goals. 

Use tools to aid your learning curve. Don’t surrender your desire on it.

text:
Founders, never let the investors be the judge of your passion and commitment.


Missing good investments is the occupational hazard of venture capitalists.
One of the biggest learning in the past year after talking to 200+ founders is , investors can never estimate the insight a founder has to the problem statement they are solving for. A phone call or a coffee meeting will never be enough. 

Founder's superpower is the ability to understand user problems and build solutions that customers may not even ask for. And investors should let curiosity anchor the conversations than making conclusions based on reports or industry thesis. You may still not get it. That's fine. When you're a VC, not all bets are winners – some are just lessons.

Btw, the market cap for Tesla today is $753 billion :) 
This excerpt is from Bessemer Venture Partner anti portfolio page.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-12-21 07:58:53', 'relative': '1 year ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1703141933216}
text:
The power of asking ⚡
This is how i got my first investor. 


Most entrepreneurs feel asking for help is a sign of weakness. But my biggest realisation is, it's actually a superpower. 

Sometimes the driving force is not in who you know, but asking for help from the unknowns. It's a powerful tool to navigate the landscape of social connections and accept the vulnerabilities of having no credentials. 

You can ask for help, feedback or suggestions. The worst outcome is no response. The best outcome can't be predicted.

When i was starting ImStrong, my last startup. I knew nothing about raising money. I knew no one in the venture capital or angel networks.

The only thing i knew was sending cold emails :) Most landed no response but some good folks did reply.  

So, i sent a cold email to Nithin Kamath. 
I expected it to land no response.
But in 10 mins i got a reply. 
In 2 days, i got an investment offer 😊 
Below is the screen shot of the exact email trails that happened. 
 
Me- Hey Nithin, we are building ImStrong. This is the problem we are solving. What do you think?

Nithin signed up as a user to try the product.
 
Me- Asked for feedback.
Nithin replied with his experience of the product. 
 
Me- Hey Nithin, would you like to invest in what we are building? Asked for the money :)

We got an investment offer within 2 days.
 
So, whatever you are building, don't shy away from asking —Asking customers to try the product. Asking potential candidates to join the team. Asking investors for money. Asking random people for suggestions or feedback. 
 
You may get many "No". All you need is that one "Yes".

text:
23 million girls in India drop out of school annually due to a lack of proper menstrual hygiene facilities.

More than 300 million women in India still don't have access to proper menstrual hygiene products. And still use old rags, ash, leaves & clothes. 

Was talking to Vikas Bagaria yesterday to understand the current situation. 

While brands will do their bit to build awareness. The biggest impact will happen when we start talking about it at home, office and in social circles. 

-Celebrating one women's day in a year doesn't do any good. 
-Men should be comfortable in breaking the silence and engage in conversations with their daughter, sister, spouse & friends. 
-Menstruation education should be everyone's business. Awareness amongst girl child is good. But should be equally important amongst young boys. 

Ignorance is the real taboo. Menstruation education is a collective responsibility. 
This video came up later internally and thought it's apt to share here.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-11-25 05:54:22', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1700888062599}
text:
Employee wellness needn’t be complicated. 

That’s Nithin, Vishnu & me crossing the finish line at IronMan Goa last month.
We participated as a corporate relay team. 

Working in a 9am-6pm work environment can be stressful. Be it corporates or startups. Employers want their teams to be healthy. And employees want to live a healthy life. 
The mismatch is in expectations.

Most employers over complicate employee wellness by pushing for programs that don't sync with everyone. But sometimes the biggest impact is driven by doing simple things. 

At Zerodha & Rainmatter playing sports is an anchor that has worked well.
Not just evangelising it but participation from top leadership to everyone in the company. 

For those interested how we do this internally. This is a link to the forum where we discussed everything from event planning, creating a team, training and more. We had three teams and everyone met each other only at the event :) 

Link: https://lnkd.in/giV8PgBA

The upside is, now we have more folks doing events for running, triathlons, obstacle racing and more. There are groups playing some sport every weekend. And all this without any complicated employee wellness program. 
People just talk to each other, signup events and show up to the start line. 

Becoming a healthy company is not an event.
It's a process.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-11-03 07:06:27', 'relative': '2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1698991587244}
text:
Why not? Such a large market opportunity here.

-100 million+ people in India are diabetic. 
-More than 50% of population are unaware of their diabetic status.
-135 million+ people are overweight or obese.
-This includes 14 million children & predicted to be 27 million by 2030.
-30% urban & 20% rural Indians have high cholesterol. 

The global packaged food and beverage industry is on the hunt for its next frontier. And India is their gold mine 🇮🇳

Why? Because this is still a country where starchy cereals, fried snacks and sugary drinks are sold as quality options on mainstream advertisement by Bollywood and sports personalities.

For these companies, India is the opportunity of next decade. 
But Indians don’t realise what is being robbed away from them. 

Only 32% of products sold in India are within the scientific thresholds recommended by the WHO. 
68% of products have excess amounts of at least one ingredient of health concern.

Your health is your business. 
You can create a health monopoly when packaged & processed food companies can’t make profit from you.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-10-26 07:49:25', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1698299365627}
text:
"Work tax" is killing Healthcare in India. 
Primary care consultations last for avg 2mins. But the waiting time to meet the doctor is avg 30mins.

Work tax is the extra time and effort required in a process or system that adds unnecessary complexity. It’s highly inefficient. In the context of healthcare, it's the excessive administrative burdens and manual tasks that healthcare providers have to go through. From obtaining signatures or filling out forms, waiting for diagnostics before they can deliver care to patients. 

This should be reduced or eliminated through automation and streamlining processes.

Why now?
Approx 86,000 crore was spent on healthcare in the India in 2022. The potential for cost reduction and improved efficiency is immense. We've to get rid of the outdated and ineffective software systems like billing, eligibility verification, and claims processing.
This is a research done highlighting the challenges of Health Information Systems in India. https://lnkd.in/ejHGq52Q

Intelligent automation using AI and sensors can make healthcare become more efficient, effective, improve the standard of care and potentially save funds for the economy. 

Use cases i can think of: 

1. Efficiency and Accuracy: Leverage the ABDM ( Ayushman Bharat Digital Mission) health stack by Indian Govt. Automate administrative tasks and workflows. Hospitals spends more time on patient care leading to improved outcomes.

2. Data-Driven Decision Making: Sensors can collect data ,identify patterns, trends, potential issues and add insights retaining the doctor's time for decision making than clerical work. There is a lot of innovation happening around continuous monitoring devices. 

3. Personalized Medicine: Use of AI to analyze patient data including medical history, genetics, and lifestyle factors. 

4.Remote Monitoring: Sensor devices can allow healthcare providers to monitor patients health from a distance & improve medication adherence. The doctor-patient ratio in India is 1:834. 

5. Care Coordination: Another use case of ABDM is to streamline electronic health records and information-sharing systems to enable seamless collaboration between hospitals, insurance and patient. 

If you are building tools to eliminate the work tax on healthcare in India, at Rainmatter we are keen to be on your side.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-10-18 10:35:26', 'relative': '2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1697618126743}
text:
Periods can stop. But you shouldn't. 
Find a way tell this to your partners and colleagues. 
Today is World Menopause Day. 

It's shocking how something that's inevitable for half the world's population is surrounded in so much secrecy and silence. Women spend nearly one-third of their lives with menopause, but there's little awareness about it.

Approx 150 million Indian women are living with menopause and the average age of menopause is 46.2 years. Compared to 51 years in western countries. Premature menopause is a big cause of mental health. 

We need to make conversations around menstruation and menopause mainstream.
- More open discussions at workplace, family and social circles. 
- Put menopause as part of school, college curriculum.
- Add it in the workplace culture manual. 

Hoping more companies, startups and brands will do their part to raise awareness. Build platforms and solutions to raise awareness and create support systems. That's the only way to improve the well-being of our partners & colleagues.

Indian Menopause Society is working to change this by educating women and their families about menopause. 
https://lnkd.in/eKqP9Zzq

posted_at: {'date': '2023-10-11 09:20:32', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1697008832694}
text:
Reimagining entrepreneurship through endurance sports. 

#11 episode and i’m talking to Gaurav Hinduja, Co-founder at axio 

In this episode we explore his other side and discuss founder depression, regaining fitness, endurance training , parenting and much more.

Links to the full podcast: 
Youtube : https://lnkd.in/gJnUDft9

Spotify: https://lnkd.in/gyzhkEz3

Apple podcast : https:/https://lnkd.in/gTY4yxmr

My notes from the podcast: 

- Founder depression is a common reality. Never show weakness and be the cheerleader in tough situations is over celebrated. 

-Stress + rest = growth. Figuring out the appropriate dose of each is key, and a moving target.

- How you perform on your average days at work or home is more important than how you perform on your great ones.

- Becoming unhealthy is not an event. It's a process. Discipline is remembering what you want.

I hope you get out and start exploring your own other side soon

If you're new to the podcast, you can find all the past video episodes here https://lnkd.in/gxHbvfJd

posted_at: {'date': '2023-10-02 07:17:24', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1696223844653}
text:
Health startups in India 🇮🇳 

There are many entrepreneurs solving for problems across different spectrum of health, fitness and nutrition.
Not every story is shared. Not every product gets visibility. 

At Rainmatter Health, we meet many founders and startups.
We may invest only in a few but each one has a reason to exist. 

When i was an entrepreneur, i wished there was an organic way of telling what we were building. But the only option was paid PR and media. 

Have decided to share every week names of startups we meet that people should know about. No strings attached. 

One of the biggest mistakes people think is that they have to be an "expert" to share about something.
But this is wrong.
The truth is, people don't want to learn from experts.
They prefer to learn from those just a few steps ahead of them on the same path. And once you realize this, it's a huge creative unlock.

If you share what you do, how you think, how you solve problems, and who you can help, the Internet will introduce you to lots and lots of people who value you!

So, every Monday,  will publish a new list of startups we met. Here’s the first of many.

Mapmygenome - Know Yourself - Personalised healthcare using genomics for preventive health.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-09-26 07:24:05', 'relative': '2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1695705845107}
text:
In 3mins, Sifan Hassan who ran the London Marathon will teach the greatest lesson for life & entrepreneurship.
Goosebumps guaranteed!

This is the story of her remarkable win.

Sifan ran her debut marathon while training through Ramadan and fasting. Was pitted against the best athletes in the world.

Day before the race she said " I'm scared & feel stupid to show up for a marathon"

-Within one hour of the race, she fell off the pace from the lead pack. 
-She was struggling with pain and stopped twice to stretch her hips.
-For elite runners, when they stop in a marathon their chances of winning is almost zero.

At this time the commentators said "She needs to stop and somebody needs to give her advice to step off and stop trying to run. She may not know what to do in a marathon".

-Sifan had the grit & resilience to stay on the course limping while her competitors raced ahead of her.
-At one point, she was nearly hit by the lead motorbike while trying to get to her water bottle. 
-Later she offered water to her rivals.
-With every kilometre she closed the gap with the leaders and soon was with the pack.
-And 400meters away from the finish line she surged leaving her competition almost impossible to catch her.

Sifan won the race with a finish time of 2hr 18min 34 sec

After the finish she said “I learned to be patient and just to run my own race. Just keep going as much as possible and maybe i'll surprise myself.”

What makes Hassan’s story even more special is that she was born in Ethiopia but moved to the Netherlands aged 15 as a refugee where she moved into a shelter for asylum seekers. 

Becoming strong is not an event. 
It's a process.
Discipline is remembering what you want.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-09-20 12:16:09', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1695204969846}
text:
Nithin Kamath & Rainmatter took bet on me three years back. I'm now taking a bet on others with the same team. Here's a backstory.

January 2020 we raised 3cr from Rainmatter & Raghunandan G for ImStrong. We were building a video streaming platform to make fitness accessible online.
We had no clue Covid will be a thing in future. And no, we were not visionaries 😊 

Both me & my co-founder Selvan Thamarai felt as working professionals we couldn't find time to go to a fitness centre.
So can we bring the fitness experience to home? That was our the problem statement

"Fitness centre is not important. Fitness is" 
That was the first line in our deck

Selvan had background in building video solutions so we built a prototype in 6 weeks. A digital tool specific for the fitness experience.

I sent a cold email to Nithin & 20 other investors. Nithin replied " Hey, i've booked a workout for tomorrow morning"

We'd just built a prototype and dint have any supply side figure out yet. I quickly called a trainer friend to come home and take the online session. After the workout, Nithin sent an email to meet him the next day.

Me & Selvan had no clue what to expect
Nithin gave feedback on the product and offered to invest. We raised 3crore at 15Cr post money valuation. This was early 2020

Then 2020-22 became a wild ride.
Everything was going online.
We got a good product adoption. 
But this meant more competition too.
The big guys were spending a lot of money to acquire customers.

We tried multiple GTM and product pivots. From ImStrong to StreamAnchor. Moved from from acquiring end consumers to selling tools to trainers and creators. Think Shopify for trainers.

Long story short. Post covid the product growth started dipping. With limited money left in the bank we decided to pull the plug in late 2022.

I'm super proud of the product we built and the experiences it delivered.
Got love from both fitness enthusiasts & trainers. 
Very grateful for the opportunity to build ImStrong.
Got to work with a stellar team and a co-founder.
Each one gave everything they had to the journey.
Deep gratitude to investors for their support.
Was lucky to have such good folks on our side.

Then early 2023 got back on the road to figure out what to do next. And then Nithin asked to help build RainMatter Health.

There is a lot happening at Rainmatter Health. So for me it's another opportunity to build something.

We are investing in companies that are helping Indians stay healthy. I shared why we do this here https://lnkd.in/gBWAZRZQ

But we want to do much more than that. More on this later.

I'm excited and thrilled to be able to continue doing what i love the most. Engaging with entrepreneurs, work on stuff related to health & fitness. A podcast talking about that https://lnkd.in/gxHbvfJd

And do all this with a bunch of super smart folks and a cheerleader Nithin

Few things i learnt along this way.
Shared in the comments below.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-09-17 06:46:20', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1694925980436}
text:
India’s real Chak De Girls. 
12 young girls from unknown villages. 
Playing a sport that is not celebrated. 
All set to represent India in Rugby at Asian Games.

Fantastic piece written by Boria Majumdar. 

What did playing sports give them?

Identity. 
In a village, where women aren’t allowed to play any form of outdoor sport. Or wear shorts. Sports gave them an identity. 

Confidence. 
No one now asks them the marriage question anymore. Even if they do, they have the confidence to say they are playing for India.

Respect.
Ask them why sports? “Girls don’t have respect. That’s what I wanted to earn for myself and that’s what rugby has given us. That’s why I want to be on the pitch for India:”

Future
What did Rugby give them? “Everyone wants a better life. You want to eat one extra egg, have an extra glass of milk or one extra piece of fish. For years, we did not have the means to do so. Whenever I wanted to have an extra piece, I would have to think that someone in the family could go hungry. Now things have changed. Now I can provide my family with a better life.”

Stories like these are the underrated source of inspiration. 
Stories like this should be shared.

Must read article https://lnkd.in/gfvGNbrk

posted_at: {'date': '2023-08-15 07:29:00', 'relative': '2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1692077340339}
text:
As long i live, i will play and win”

That’s Bhagwani Devi. 
A 95-year-old athlete from Delhi ✨ 

She won three gold medals for India at the World Masters Athletics Indoor Championships at Poland. 🥇 

Not just in one sports. But three different sports- 60mtr running, shot put and discus throw.

After the championship she said “As long i live, i will play and win”

She was not an athlete in her younger days. 
Had hardships all through her growing years. 
Lost husband & one son in her 30’s. 
Worked at farm to earn a living.

Started playing sports at the young age of 94 encouraged by her grandson Vikas Dagar—a national para-athlete.

Training at this age is not easy. But she now has a competent team that manages all aspects of her strength, nutrition & fitness.

Sport is a great way to stay healthy. 
Find what is fun to you. 
Makes you move. 
And you enjoy the most. 

Bhagwani Devi found the athlete in her in 90’s.
I found mine in my mid 30’s. 
Good luck to finding the athlete in you!

posted_at: {'date': '2023-08-11 07:22:49', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1691731369311}
text:
Rainmatter Health
A cheerleader for Indians to be healthy. 

What is it? 
Rainmatter Health is a giving forward initiative by the team at Zerodha. It’s a health focused fund to support founders and invest in startups that are building products and solutions for Indians to make healthier choices. 
To eat right, exercise more and sleep well. 

The goal of the fund is not just to generate financial returns but to make an impact and any profits from the investments will mostly go back to supporting more entrepreneurs. 

More thoughts on this by Nithin https://lnkd.in/gfZ3Zvnh

Time & Wealth are two biggest compounding assets.  
What you do with it matters. 
How much you have should not matter. 
This is the credo at Rainmatter.

In the health fund,
We are a team of health and fitness enthusiasts. 
We cheer for everyone around us to stay healthy. 
We cheer for entrepreneurs who want to make others healthy.

India has massive health problems. And it needs to be solved now. 
➡️100 million+ people in India are diabetic. 
More than 50% of people are unaware of their diabetic status.

➡️135 million+ people in India are overweight or obese.
This includes 14.4 million children predicted to be 27 million by 2030.

➡️60 million+ people suffer from common and severe mental health issues. 
India is the world's suicide capital.

➡️138 million people in India are 60 years & above.
 Predicted to touch 194 million by 2031. 

➡️One in every 10 women in India has PCOS.
70% of Indian women suffer cramping during periods and still is a neglected issue in most households.

➡️India has the highest growth rate for ultra-processed food and beverages.
Only 32% of products are within the scientific thresholds recommended by the WHO. 68% of products have excess amounts of at least one ingredient of health concern.

Health issues in India are complex and multifaceted, and they require a unique approach to solve and bring impact. 
Can be solved using technology or otherwise.
And needs to be solved by more than one company. 

If you are building a product for health, nutrition and fitness. 
We want to partner and support you. More about us on https://rainmatter.com
You can also reach out to Dilip Kumar or Sagar Gudekote 

The team is more than the two of us 😊
We’ve footballers, trekkers, weight lifters, cyclists, runners. Men & women who are sports and fitness enthusiasts 😊

Will be soon launching a new series of podcasts focused on startups in health.  
You can also join the discussions here https://lnkd.in/gVejk-jW 

These are some companies we've partnered at Rainmatter Health.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-08-09 11:45:01', 'relative': '2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1691574301044}
text:
Why is there so much misinformation around health?
How can it be fixed?

This has been on top of my mind for a long time and the reason to have this podcast with Dr Abby Philips.
He is a specialist in Hepatology and Liver Transplant. He did his MBBs , MD & DM and is the president's gold medal winner for academic excellence. 
He has 200+ research papers published to him.

But there is an interesting other side of him.
He is known as TheLiverDoc on Twitter for his work as a crusader against all sort of misinformation on health and pseudoscience. 
He is a father of three, an avid gamer and a graphic novel enthusiast 😊
Follow his work on Twitter https://lnkd.in/gHqX2jQD

There is a lot we discussed:
-- The reason to be TheLiverDoc on Twitter. You know what i mean :)
-- How that happened and why it remains important.
--The universe of quackery & pseudoscience in nutrition, health & fitness.
--Healthcare landscape in India. How modern ,alternative & integrative medicine works.
--Business of health and patient care.
--Debunking myths around supplements & nutraceuticals. 
--Do's & Don'ts for individuals to create their own health protocols.
--Alcohol, Coffee, Artificial sweetener, Intermittent fasting,Proteins, Carbs, multivitamins and much more.
--Life of a doctor beyond medical practice.

I've to say this upfront.
This conversation is not to prove anything good or bad. But to establish some tools and frameworks that everyone can use to create their own guard rail for health.

It's 3.5hr+ podcast. I don't expect you to listen or watch it at one go. Maybe you should not. But when you finish, do make an attempt to relay your thoughts to improve the scientific temperament of people around you. That will improve their understanding of health.

There are a lot to takeways from this conversation and I hope this is useful to you.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-07-24 07:52:19', 'relative': '2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1690177939936}
text:
Women at work, can be an athlete.
Women at home, can be an athlete.

Both of these women are an example of this. And i'm sure there are many more out there. There are a ton of notes i made from my conversations with Rashmi & Nirupa. Here are few on top of the list.

-Staying fit for your own goal is fun. And it shows.
Staying fit for someone else’s goal is work. And it shows.

-Stress + rest = growth. 
Figuring out the appropriate dose of each is key, and a moving target.

-How you perform on your average days at work or home is more important than how you perform on your great ones.

-Becoming unhealthy is not an event. It's a process. 
Discipline is remembering what you want.

-Everyone teaches motivation. 
But no one learns determination.

-Learn when to prioritise yourself and when not to. 
You will be unstoppable if you have the judgement.

-The progress in your mental & physical health is the gap between your own desire and commitment. 

-If you avoid all the risks in life. You will never find what you’re a capable of.

My full conversation with both of them are on

posted_at: {'date': '2023-07-07 10:44:12', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1688719452028}
text:
Winning matters.
But how you win matters the most.

This is one of my favourite moments in long distance running history.

Kenyan runner Abel Mutai was just a few feet away from the finish line, and got confused with the signage. He stopped thinking he had completed the race.

A Spanish athlete, Ivan Fernandez, was right behind him, and realised the Kenyan was confused and started shouting asking him to continue running, but Mutai didn't understand Spanish. 

Fernandez eventually caught up to him and instead of passing him, slowed down to push Mutai from behind to make him cross the finish line. 

Mutai Won. Fernandez was second. 

After the race, he was asked- "Why did you do that?"

Ivan said, “My dream is that someday we can have a kind of community life where we push and help each other to win. I didn't let him win, he was going to win. What would be the merit of my victory if i'd overtaken him. What would my Mom think of that?”

Sometimes true victory is not just in personal success but also getting others closer to their wins.

If there is someone pushing you to win, take time to celebrate them.
If there is someone you pushed to win, you are a special person.

text:
Should we be happy or sad for this ranking. 

Happy because why not. 

Sad because either our population still doesn’t understand what depression feels like or doesn’t have access to right medical care. 

That’s dangerous. 

According to the 2015 National Mental Health Survey (NHMS) one in every 20 Indians, or 5.3% of the population, was found to have suffered from depressive disorders at some point in their lives. 

Have the situation changed drastically?

Unicef reports that one out of seven young people between the ages of 15 to 24 in India always feels depressed or has little interest in doing things. 

Depression can be fatal. 

Mental health should be the priority as with physical.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-06-01 11:04:30', 'relative': '2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1685610270509}
text:
How humans seated for hours and barely moving can loose 6000 calories a day. This will blow your mind. 
It's called the grandmaster diet. 

↘ In 1984, world champion Anatoly Karpov lost 10kg at the end of the tournament. 
↘ In 2004, world champion Rustam Kasimdzhanov lost 8kg.

Chess players can burn up to 6,000 calories a day.
That's three times what an average person consumes in a day.

So, how does a sedentary sport like chess burn so much calories?

This is the wild part.
It all comes from stress.

Throughout long championships, chess players have to endure immense stress.

You may not be a grandmaster but there is something for you to takeaway.

Let's understand more.

As one gets stressed, their heart rate (HR) increases. 
This rise in HR forces the body to produce more energy. 
and can cause a person’s breathing rate to triple. 
As the human body receives this extra oxygen, blood pressure increases and metabolism speeds up, which in turn, causes the body to burn calories.

The primary way chess burns calories is through the use of brain. And for a mentally challenging activity like chess, brain uses more energy. Grandmasters sustain elevated blood pressure for hours in the range found in elite marathoners.

Stress and anxiety are the greatest drivers of this weight loss phenomenon. 

Is it good? Definitely not 🔴
The overwork of brain can cause increased stress, loss of appetite& disturbed sleep.

So what do chess players do to train themselves to be sharp and competitive? 

Here's what the greatest of all time Viswanathan Anand and Magnus Carlsen did. 

Fix their exercise & nutrition strategy ✅

Anand would do two hours of cardio each night to tire himself out so he doesn't dream about chess. He would go for a run or climb on the morning of almost all of his chess matches to keep a high heart rate. 

During the 2001 World Championship Anand’s car was caught in a traffic jam with just minutes left for the game. He abandoned his car and sprinted into the playing hall to start a crucial encounter.

Carlsen in 2017 was still winning most tournaments, but his matches were lasting longer & the victories were less assured. 
He was loosing energy in the last hour of games. 
Fixing his nutrition brought the big change. 

Till then he used to mostly rely on mix of half orange juice & water for an energy boost. But as he evolved to his late 20s, his body was no longer breaking down the sugar as quickly, leading to glucose crashes. He replaced juices to a mixture of chocolate milk and plain milk, which contained far lower levels of sugar but would also supplement his body with calcium, potassium and protein. 
This kept his blood sugar at a reasonable level without too big a variation.

In a recent interview, Anand said " The most important thing to combat stress is building stamina. In chess, you want to handle handle 6 hours of absolute focus and not make your brain tired. When you get tired you tend to forget things and then blunders happen"

posted_at: {'date': '2023-05-22 12:33:51', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1684751631264}
text:
India is running
27000 people ran the TCS 10k in Bangalore yesterday. 

13000+ ran 10km (2900 female & 10000+ male )
14000+ ran 5km
And numerous visually impaired and disabled runners.

We have 1.7 billion population.
But 2.5 million runners estimated. 
Not even amongst the top 20 countries with most runners.

But we will be there. Soon.
Growth in number of people taking up to running is encouraging.
10yo kid to 90 yo grandma.
 People are lacing up their shoes to get fit.

So, how can we get more people to run?
More people to show up for local races?
Perhaps by doing small things right first.

Organisers job is tough.
Making race experience delightful is hard.
Kudos to everyone who are on their feet for weeks leading up to such events.

I ran the TCS10k yesterday. 
And few things i noticed that could be fixed for a better experience.

1) Traffic woes kills the excitement. 
The parking situation yesterday was a chaos.
Felt there were more vehicles than runners. What can be done?
-Arrange for a public transport system for the race day.
-Create a system that allows people to carpool.
-This can cut the vehicular movement to more than 50%.

2) One event shouldn't damage the environment.
Although the organisers promised green initiatives.
The roads were littered with plastic water bottles.
More than 1lac water bottles must have been used yesterday.
What can be done?
-Replace water bottles with refuelling station.
-Only fast runners prefer not to stop. They are less than 10% of the participants.
- Cutting plastic waste is is a huge saving both on cost and environmental damage.

3) Marble cake & a carbonated drink given post run 😊 
Drink & eat for recovery. Not for taste.
WHO recommends consuming protein within 30mins of an intensive activity. What can be done?
-Replace the juices/carbonated drinks with a ready to drink protein shake.
-Instead of a chocolate give a banana.
- It's worth the extra bucks.

Hoping to see more runners on the roads 🙂 

Did you run the TCS10k? #tcsw10k

posted_at: {'date': '2023-05-18 12:12:20', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1684404740572}
text:
GOALS
They look far and hazy unless you keep chasing them. 
Every day, every week, every month.


In 2020, I set a goal to run a Sub 3hr marathon. 
For 4months, I was chasing this goal. It was up on my wall 😊 
To become Sub 3 marathoner.

And every week, I got two inch closer.

I’ll wake up and stare at the wall reminiscing all the past training and before going to bed muster whatever left for the next day.

Marathon training is just learning to be bored while you're hurting. 

Did i meet my goal? ...Yes, I finished 2:59:52 😌 
But those 16 weeks changed me a lot.
as an entrepreneur,
as a colleague,
as a husband,
as a friend,
and as an athlete.

There are maybe 100 men in India who can run Sub3hr marathon.
I'm one of them.
Today a 2:55:58 Marathoner.
Head high, heart full.

Everyone teaches motivation. But no one learns discipline.
Motivation is in abundance. Discipline is scarce. 

The progress in your goals is the gap between your desire and commitment. 

This is the exact training plan i followed to become a Sub3hr marathoner 😊 👇 


I host a podcast called  "The Other Side” 
Video https://lnkd.in/gxHbvfJd
Audio https://pod.link/dilip

posted_at: {'date': '2023-04-25 11:07:42', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1682413662355}
text:
In 3mins, Sifan Hassan from London Marathon will teach you the greatest lesson for life & entrepreneurship.
Goosebumps guaranteed!

Sifan ran her debut marathon while training through Ramadan and fasting and was pitted against the best athletes in the world.

Day before the race she said " I'm scared & feel stupid to show up for a marathon"

This is the story of her remarkable win this past Sunday.

-Within one hour of the race, she fell off the pace from the lead pack. 
-She was struggling with pain and stopped twice to stretch her hips.
-For elite runners, when they stop in a marathon their chances of winning is almost zero.

At this time the commentators said "She needs to stop and somebody needs to give her advice to step off and stop trying to run on. She may not know what to do in a marathon".

-But Sifan showed grit & resilience to stay on the course limping while her competitors raced ahead of her.
-At one point, she was nearly hit by the lead motorbike while trying to get to her water bottle. 
-Later she offered water to her rivals.
-With every kilometre she closed the gap with the leaders and soon was with the pack.
-And 400meters away from the finish line she surged leaving her competition almost impossible to catch her.

Sifan won the race with a finish time of 2hr 18min 34 sec

After the finish she said “I learned to be patient and just to run my own race. Just keep going as much as possible and maybe i'll surprise myself.”

What makes Hassan’s story even more special is that she was born in Ethiopia but moved to the Netherlands aged 15 as a refugee where she moved into a shelter for asylum seekers. 

Becoming strong is not an event. 
It's a process.
Discipline is remembering what you want. 

On Twitter I’m at  https://lnkd.in/gz7TJyxi 

Video source BBC

posted_at: {'date': '2023-04-07 06:38:43', 'relative': '2 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1680842323827}
text:
“As long i live, i will play and win”

That’s Bhagwani Devi. 
A 95-year-old athlete from Delhi ✨ 

She won three gold medals for India at the World Masters Athletics Indoor Championships at Poland. 🥇 

Not just in one sports. But three different sports- 60mtr running, shot put and discus throw.

After the championship she said “As long i live, i will play and win”

She was not an athlete in her younger days. 
Had hardships all through her growing years. 
Lost husband & one son in her 30’s. 
Worked at farm to earn a living.

Started playing sports at the young age of 94 encouraged by her grandson Vikas Dagar—a national para-athlete.

Training at this age is not easy. But she now has a competent team that manages all aspects of her strength, nutrition & fitness.

Sport is a great way to stay healthy. 
Find what is fun to you. 
Makes you move. 
And you enjoy the most. 

Bhagwani Devi found the athlete in her in early 90’s.
I found mine in my mid 30’s. 
Good luck to finding the athlete in you!

posted_at: {'date': '2023-04-05 12:26:29', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1680690389854}
text:
School & college failed to teach me health & fitness.
Neither did my family. 
So I ignored it till my mid 30's. 

Then to fix my own health, I spent the last few years studying and experimenting nutrition & exercise physiology.

I went from an 32yo overweight and unhealthy person to a 40yo competitive endurance athlete. 

Here’s what i learned in 3 simple frameworks

1. What you eat is extremely important.
And when you eat and how much is equally important.

-Don't consume food or drink that comes in boxes, bags or cans, the stuff loaded with refined grains, sugar
-Eat a high protein nutrient dense diet
-Cook your own food
^That will be your superpower.

2. You don't need to have a six-pack.
Exercise to feel confident and prevent disease.

Your desk job is destroying your body and ruining your health.

-Lift weights, workout at home or play a sport. Just move your body
-Consistency is way more valuable than intensity. 
-We lose muscle as we age. 
-If you ignore gaining muscle, you will become weak, more susceptible to injuries and ultimately live with pain all day long.
-Strength training will recreate the best version of yourself.

The biggest lie you should ignore is that cardio kills muscle growth.

3. Stress is your biggest enemy. 
And sleep is your biggest performance enhancer.

-Stress + rest = growth. 
Figuring out the appropriate dose of each is key.
-Your hospital visits won't teach you this. 
Because they make money on your ignorance.
-Stop eating 3 hours before bed.
-Stop looking at screens 1 hour before bed.
-Train yourself to deal with stress with exercise instead of surrendering to junk food or alcohol.

Be curious and read scientific literature. Not clickbait articles.

It's never too late to take charge of your health.
Good luck!

I host a podcast called  "The Other Side” that explores stories like these and beyond. 

Video https://lnkd.in/gxHbvfJd
Audio https://pod.link/dilip

posted_at: {'date': '2023-02-22 08:15:28', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1677050128943}
text:
Is crying good for you?


I've a 20mo at home and he cries a lot. Often there is no particular reason. I suppose that's common in most households. Science says crying can be normal amongst toddlers and is a healthy way to express their emotion.

But I got more interested in this subject. And wanted to find if crying is good for adults? 

In Japan, there are "crying clubs" called rui-katsu where people come together to cry and release stress.

- Researchers have established that crying releases oxytocin and endogenous opioids normally known as endorphins. These are good chemicals that helps to ease both physical and emotional pain.

- Crying can also help to activate the parasympathetic nervous system and regulate the temperature of your brain.

- Studies have found that emotional tears contain higher levels of stress hormones and can help to release tension and restore the body to a state of balance.

- Crying can lower blood pressure and pulse rate, remove toxins from the body, reduce manganese levels. 

In some sports you will see players crying after the match instead of fist-pumping and screaming. 

Most of the research on this topic has been to understand effects of crying on a person's mood. There are physiological, cognitive, and benefits. 

Conclusion: Crying can be a self-soothing behavior and has both direct and socially-mediated effects on a person's mood.

Research references:
1) https://lnkd.in/gT3hUmd8
2) https://lnkd.in/gT3hUmd8
3) https://lnkd.in/g9uRffnV
4)https://lnkd.in/gPr3f5UM

text:
GOALS


To live in the moment.

That’s Nike founder Phil Knight. 
The only person in the stand enjoying the moment as Lebron James takes the shot to break the all time NBA scoring record. 

Everyone else busy taking the picture.

Pic credit: ESPN

posted_at: {'date': '2023-02-04 11:52:37', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1675507957897}
text:
Priyanka Gupta asked me why the heck i'm so keen to prioritise fitness. And it took 60 mins to explain the "Why". 

I hope our conversation is useful in some way. 

Please remember, becoming unhealthy is not an event. It is a process. Like a plane crash, becoming unhealthy is rarely caused by one thing going wrong. Usually, it is a series of ignorance— lack of physical exercise, compromising on sleep, food choices & stress.  All these will interact and then compound. I realised the process late in my life though. 

It's very rare to meet people who are driven by genuine curiosity and passion to learn a new skill. Priyanka is one of them. 

Link to the full podcast in the comment section below.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-02-03 08:25:07', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1675409107150}
text:
Nithin Kamath invites competition. But not in stock brokerage. 


You should watch the full episode to understand why every entrepreneur should also be a sports person. All the guest i spoke with on my podcast have this common trait of playing some sport. Why?

Ofcourse you gain fitness.

But there are benefits beyond that. What are they?

- Develops a mindset to deal with pressure and competition. 
- Builds mental models for proactive thinking and problem solving. 
- Learning from injuries will prepare you to handle failures. 
- Builds mental toughness. Every game starts with zero. 
- Teamwork. Giving up the ‘Me’ for the ‘We’.
- Sometimes playing defense can be a superpower. 
- Everyone has a shelf life. Nithin calls it the ‘energy efficiency’ 

What sport do you play that has benefitted you the most? 

#fitness  #podcast #entrepreneur #startup #sports #health

posted_at: {'date': '2023-01-23 10:30:00', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1674466200633}
text:
The third episode of "The Other Side" is here.

My guest this time is Rishi Vasudev 

Rishi is the Co-founder & CEO of GOAT Brand Labs.  One of India's largest D2C aggregator. He was the SVP at Flipkart  & Myntra and built their fashion business and has been a CEO of multiple high-growth companies such as Lifestyle International Pvt Ltd  & Calvin Klein.   

So obviously you would expect us to talk about E-commerce, fashion, startups & scaling brands. Well, we discussed none of this. 

We spoke how playing different sports after 40 shaped his professional and personal life. Learning tennis, squash & journey with long distance running while building a startup.  His physical fitness routine & approach to managing stress. His current training for marathons. And the secret to keep playing different sports as you age. 

Rishi spoke about his goal for Tata Mumbai half marathon. Quick update: He finished 10 mins faster than his target 🙂 

You will go out and start playing a sport after exploring the other side of Rishi. 

He also shared the top three areas he would like to invest in health & fitness startups.

posted_at: {'date': '2023-01-16 07:38:30', 'relative': '2 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1673851110852}
text:
A poignant reminder to everyone. Watch this now. You could be a founder, C level executive, manager, team leader or just getting into professional world. 

Recalling the evocative thoughts shared by Nithin & Rajiv in the podcast earlier https://lnkd.in/g5yPHgC9

Nithin -  "How you take care of your health post 35 is what determines quality of life post 60. Backcasting is a powerful tool. Start working on it today."

Rajiv - "If the avg lifespan is 80, after 37.5 years of age you’re no longer a time billionaire. You don’t have more than billion seconds to live. That’s the time wealth everyone has got. Regardless what your net worth is or assets you have made. Invest your time on your health."

Third episode of the podcast releases end of this week.

posted_at: {'date': '2020-11-16 09:49:06', 'relative': '5 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1605516546718}
text:
The most efficient Diwali greeting campaign.

100% delivery rate ⚡️
95% response rate  😊
Took 15 mins  

Every year during Diwali/New year I receive tons of greeting messages. And now with Whatsapp it’s just easy to forward images, videos, stickers and GIFs. 
But they all lack the personal warmth and i don’t click or open any. 

This time, I did a hack to deliver personalised greetings. 15 second personalised voice message to 60 people on WhatsApp. Nothing fancy. Simple greeting with individual name and added the family member names if i know them. 
Avg 15 secs x 60 messages = 15 minutes of gratitude. 

And almost 95% replied back with their personal greetings :) 

Relationships also need some manual effort. Too much automation spoils the fun.

posted_at: {'date': '2020-11-03 07:27:26', 'relative': '5 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1604384846733}
text:
We had users from 100+ countries in the previous month 🌎

And spent zero money on marketing. 
Yes, we are building a global digital fitness product without flashy marketing ads or celebrity endorsement. 

Money can never drive growth. Good product and better user experiences will. 

1,00,000+ fitness classes engaged between fitness seekers and trainers in last 7 months. And most importantly MOM growth. 

Fitness is not about giving free video content. 
It's about delivering an outcome. And technology is a powerful enabler to do that.  

Grateful to be working with a brilliant 12 member team. Engineering driven & a growth mindset. Thankful to all the amazing trainers using our platform to deliver outcomes to fitness seekers from around the world. 

We are just getting started 🚀

posted_at: {'date': '2020-08-05 13:54:53', 'relative': '5 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1596628493979}
text:
The power of asking ⚡
 
Most entrepreneurs start with a great product idea and a conviction to work on that. There’s something equally important — the power of asking. 
 
Here is how that led us to our first investor.
 
I asked a common friend to make an introduction to Nithin Kamath
 
This is the summary 👇
 
Me- Hey Nithin, we are building ImStrong. This is the problem we are solving. What do you think?
Nithin signed up as a user to try the product.
 
Me- Asked for feedback.
Nithin replied with his experience of the product. 
 
Me- Hey Nithin, would you like to invest in what we are building? Asked for the money :)

We got a meeting and then an investment offer within a span of 2 days.
 
We couldn’t have got a better investor to begin with.
Nithin is an awesome partner, supporter & a well wisher.
 
And we continue our streak for asking for help and and he is always cheering with his support.
 
So, whatever you are building, don't shy away from asking —Asking customers to try the product. Asking potential candidates to join the team. Asking investors for money.
 
You may get many "No". All you need is that one "Yes".

STIRAH SUKAH ASANA - extols the value of being Steady and At Ease. Interestingly, Hatha Yoga gives a precise time that you should be able to be hold your seated pose to master it or 'Asan Siddh' - 2h 32min. (usually Siddhasana or even Padmasana)

How long can you Sit 'Steady, yet At Ease' today? Join us through February as we share a 21 Day Program, training you in Asana, Pranayam, Meditation, Cleansing so that everyday you can add a minute to your Sitting. Starting with 10 mins, we'll get to 30 mins by the 21st of February, which is Maha Shivratri - the most auspicious night to experience Meditation.

You can follow the Program from your home on https://lnkd.in/fwcmQZv

Come with me on an adventure to Master just 1 Yoga pose - it's all that you'll really need!

reshared_post:
{'urn': {'activity_urn': '6621011004220411904', 'share_urn': '6621011003368964097', 'ugcPost_urn': None}, 'posted_at': {'date': '2020-01-09 13:13:55', 'relative': '5 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1578572035842}, 'text': "10 musts in 2020 for a healthier YOU.

1. Sitting is the new smoking - Don't sit for long. Sitting is really bad for your health, and it can't be reversed by any amount of exercise. I stand and work most of the time. 

2. Eat a minimum of 3 different fruits 30 minutes before every meal - I have been following this for the last 4.5 years, and I haven't been to a doctor, and I am so energetic.

3. Drink enough water to hydrate your body. We are 60% water, and water intake has too many advantages. 

4. Drink vegetable soup, and have a light dinner (No rice, wheat, non-veg, etc.). 

5. 15 min walk a must after dinner. This has helped me much to reduce fat on my tummy.

6. 45 min of exercise with no music, starting with stretching, cardio, and Yoga.

7. 15 minutes of no mind meditation will reduce your stress level by 60-90%.

8. Brush twice a day and massage your gums with coconut oil. Your teeth will be healthy.

9. Do not drink coffee/tea in the morning. Instead, boil Ginger in water and add palm jaggery (a rich source of minerals).

10. Avoid anything white (Refined sugar, salt, oil, wheat, rice, etc.)

How many of these you don't follow? Share your thoughts.

reshared_post:
{'urn': {'activity_urn': '6607873909188591616', 'share_urn': '6607873908416835584', 'ugcPost_urn': None}, 'posted_at': {'date': '2019-12-04 07:11:48', 'relative': '6 years ago • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1575439908311}, 'text': "YOGA + TECH series
PRANA & PRANAYAMA
___________________
.
As Yogis, we believe that the entire cosmos is throbbing with Prana!
.
Understanding Prana as 'Livingness' allows us to better appreciate how Fundamental it is - to manage our Prana levels for our mental, physical, emotional & spiritual wellbeing.
.
This is not merely about getting in more Oxygen - in fact during most Pranayama practice we breathe slowly and thereby breathe in less Oxygen. So Prana isn't the air we breathe in, but it's more subtle - 'Livingness'.
.
Join me as we understand PRANA & practice PRANAYAMA together on this Fri & Sat between 7 - 7:30am (India time).
.
This is a free Broadcast on @imstrong.co whom I've partnered with exclusively to Teach Yoga and Meditation online. 

Here's the link https://lnkd.in/fwcmQZv

text:
At ImStrong, it's our mission to help people live a healthy life with a strong mind and body. And Manish is one of the most brilliant Mindfulness and Yoga coaches we are proud to partner with in this endeavor. 

As he says "Everyone today wants to find a bit of silence and space in this hyper-sensory world". We are always chasing targets, milestones, growth or fundraise. What are we doing to fuel our mind and body to achieve that?

More about Manish and his guided yoga and mindfulness sessions on ImStrong here https://lnkd.in/fUtHaqy

#yoga #mindfulness #healthylife

text:
A fit body, a calm mind, a house full of love. These things cannot be bought, they must be earned - Naval Ravikant

As startup founders, how much time do you invest in your mental & physical fitness?

Founders priority list presented by Adora Cheung at YCombinator last week 👇

posted_at: {'date': '2019-09-16 07:53:22', 'relative': '6 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1568613202515}
text:
Live video streaming is the solution for busy working population to access fitness with convenience. At ImStrong we are super excited to have support from backers who believe in this vision and are perhaps amongst the fittest entrepreneurs in the ecosystem. Nithin Kamath, an avid fitness enthusiast, and Raghunandan G , endurance sports and multiple Ironman finisher and Austin P., an MMA & Boxing champ. 

A massive opportunity we are addressing at ImStrong is helping the 200+ million working population to get fit and live a healthy life.

posted_at: {'date': '2018-06-06 12:21:52', 'relative': '7 years ago • Edited • Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn', 'timestamp': 1528280512254}
text:
Whoever said "Entrepreneurship is not a sprint but a marathon" is damn right. And what better way to take that advice and blend it with your health. 

Running not just helped me maintain an active lifestyle and stay fit but actually taught the real principles of endurance, patience, and persistence. It made me a better endurance athlete and a patient entrepreneur. Fit is a term that describes a variety of things. For me, it's a verb that defines the balance between body & mind. 

Ran a 25k this weekend, 16k on Tue and 6k today. https://lnkd.in/eumPX5w

What are your doing? Run, Swim, Bike, Bodyweights or Gym

#humfittohindiafit #IndiaFitnessChallengeAccepted #GlobalRunningDay
My challenge is to Raghunandan G, Aneesh Reddy, Abhishek Roy Lizzie Chapman (Dharma) Dharmendra Kumar

Pic taken at New Delhi Marathon 2018.
